speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The purpose of this bill is to repeal the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act 1946.
In 1998, a detailed review of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act was undertaken pursuant to the Government's Legislation Review Schedule.

The need to review the act was first identified in 1995 by the then Labor Government as part of its development of a regulation review timetable following on from the national Competition Principles Agreement signed by all governments in April of that year.

The Legislation Review found that the Government's training reform process, in particular the development of Training Packages and the introduction of the Australian Recognition Framework, has removed the ongoing need and rationale for the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act.

The report of the Legislation Review concluded that Registered Training Organisations established under the Australian Recognition Framework are better able to provide trade skills assessment services and there is no longer any need for the Commonwealth to do so. The report recommends that the act be repealed.

Madam President, 1996 saw the fiftieth anniversary of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act. At that time I noted that for fifty years, it had played an important role in helping to meet Australia's trades skill needs, predominantly in the metal and electrical trades.

After the Second World War it aided in the task of re-settling returning troops into the civilian workforce and reconstructing Australia's economy. It also allowed people who developed their trade skills in industry during the war to receive the appropriate recognition for those skills.

By 1951 it was considered that the legislation had achieved its immediate post-war objectives and the act was amended to also provide for the recognition of the trades skills of migrants after they arrive in Australia. Since then, newly arrived migrants have been the main client group seeking to have their skills recognised under the legislation.

The value of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act has been the nationally accepted trade qualification issued under it. Until the introduction in 1998 of the Australian Recognition Framework, there was no alternative national mechanism due to a lack of uniformity in trade training and recognition systems at the state level.
Consequently, the act provided a means for the national recognition and mobility of skills that did not otherwise exist.

The importance of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act in this regard was reinforced by a review of the act undertaken in 1991 by Mr B H Tregillis. The Tregillis review recommended that the act should continue "until national standards and processes have been developed and unless and until it can be demonstrated that a more effective mechanism [than the act] can be put in place."
The conditions for repealing the act identified by the Tregillis review have been met by the development of Training Packages and the Australian Recognition Framework.
In November 1996, Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers for Vocational Education and Training endorsed the National Training Framework.

The aims of the National Training Framework are to provide a more flexible and simpler regulatory environment for training and to underpin the user choice arrangements of the Government's New Apprenticeships initiative.
The National Training Framework comprises two elements—Training Packages and the Australian Recognition Framework.
Training Packages are developed by industry to provide the basis for the delivery of training and the assessment of skills on a consistent national basis.

The Australian Recognition Framework commenced on 1 January 1998. It is a new set of administrative arrangements for the flexible but consistent national recognition of skills against the benchmarks established by Training Packages.

The Australian Recognition Framework devolves the delivery of training and the issuing of qualifications to Registered Training Organisations which operate under a quality assurance framework administered by the States and Territories.

Madam President, at 30 June 1998 there were 195,500 apprentices and trainees in training throughout Australia. More than 60,000 of these were in trades covered by the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act. The Australian Recognition Framework governs the way these and future apprentices and trainees are trained and have their skills recognised.

The Legislation Review notes that the importance of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act has been declining in comparison to the domestic training system, and in absolute terms for some time. In 1997/98 there were only 1,218 applications for trades skill recognition under the act.
The Legislation Review notes that much of the recent decline in demand for recognition under the act reflects the changes that have occurred in the domestic training system.

Madam President, it is appropriate that the Australian Recognition Framework, which governs the operation of the domestic training system for nearly 200,000 apprentices and trainees, also applies in the recognition of the trades skills of little more than 1,200 applicants under the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act.

The Legislation Review concludes that the services provided under the act can now be delivered on a nationally consistent and competitive basis by Registered Training Organisations under the Australian Recognition Framework, and that the continuation of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act would be inconsistent with the training reform agenda which is supported by all levels of government and industry.

Madam President, the Legislation Review committee consulted widely in the course of the review, and the action it has recommended is strongly supported; including by the Australian National Training Authority, state and territory government training authorities, and the Australian Chamber of Industry and Commerce.

In its comments on an interim report circulated by the review committee, the Federation of Ethnic Community Councils of Australia said that it "appreciates that the time has come to repeal the [Tradesmen's Rights Regulation] Act".
Madam President, the Government accepts the Legislation Review's findings.

This is not about cost savings. The services provided under the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act have been increasingly self-funding since the introduction of fees by the Hawke Government in 1989, and the savings accruing to the Commonwealth from the act's repeal will be less than $500,000 per annum.

Madam President, the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act has played a valuable role, but with the advent of recent domestic training reforms that provide a more appropriate and efficient alternative, that role has come to an end.

This bill constitutes the necessary first step in implementing the recommendations of the review. The second step is the promulgation of Regulations to ensure a smooth transition to the new arrangements and, in particular, safeguard the rights of persons who currently have an application in the system.
A communication strategy will ensure that all stakeholders fully understand both the transitional and new arrangements.
Madam President, in closing, I would like to acknowledge the contribution made by a very great many people over the past 50 years to the operation of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the winter sittings 1999, in accordance with standing order 111.

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering Democrat amendments 2 to 16 on sheet 1353 revised, relating to the GST treatment of food in respect of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998 . The question is that the Democrat amendments be agreed to.

—The Democrats are in the business of delivering the economic benefits of tax reform to all people. However, we want to ensure that the new tax system is fairer than the current system, because we believe the current system is also flawed, and that is especially so for low income earners. As we have said before, the best and permanent way to compensate families for the adverse effects of a GST is to ensure that it does not deliver adverse effects in the first place. A food-free GST will minimise these adverse effects. We have been arguing that it is fairer to exempt food than to compensate people for having to pay for it. Compensation does not work, as we have said, because its effect will be eroded and the government would be compensating for something that is fundamentally unfair in the first place.

speech.para: The case for zero rating food is about equity, health, employment and economic and international best practice criteria. I want to address this issue from four particular points of view. There are four statements about the GST on food that we believe to be critical. They are: that a GST on food would be particularly damaging to remote communities; that a GST on food would be unfair to low income earners; that a GST on food would not be conducive to good eating habits; and that a GST on food would not be good for job retention in rural food production.

I would like to concentrate on the disadvantage to remote and rural communities and the issue of job retention in rural food production. Let us talk, first of all, about the issue of remote communities. It is known that food in remote communities is already far more expensive than it is for the rest of us. When we look at remote Aboriginal communities, we find very low average incomes. These two issues combine to affect very seriously the nutrition of people living in those communities.

I visit communities regularly and, as I indicated earlier in my speech in the second reading debate, particularly was shocked to visit Aurukun on the western side of Cape York last year in November. Having visited that community over a period of 20 years on a number of occasions, I was shocked to see the decline in the social and environmental health of the people there. Compared with what I saw 20 years ago, when there were many problems, what is happening there at the present time is quite devastating.

Because incomes are so low in these communities, a very high proportion of the income is spent on food, and these people are already constrained by a monopoly of supply and delivery and significant lack of choice. As a significantly disadvantaged group already, they would be further disadvantaged by a GST on food, and it will seek only to exaggerate the divisions not simply between rich and poor but between city and rural dwellers.
There is another issue—that is, the loss of jobs in rural food producing areas. Both the Murphy and the Monash models, when they examined the effect of applying a GST to food—

talk.start.para: —You weren't there, John.

—I can read. They predicted a significant loss of jobs across the agricultural sector—more bad news for regional and rural communities. I have yet to see the model that tells us that you can apply a GST to food and not have job losses in these fresh food producing areas. Further, the Murphy model showed that zero rating of food would double the positive effect of tax reform for agriculture.

speech.para: Now I want to record what the various agricultural bodies have said about the tax package, particularly about the GST. It is true that the National Farmers Federation has called for a broad-based GST and strongly opposes any narrowing of the base to which the GST applies. But there are food producing sectors which are not members of the NFF or, even if they are, disagree with the position the NFF has taken. I would point out that the NFF position was fixed last November before any of the Senate committees had met and before any of the evidence had been examined.

talk.start.para: —Like your position.
—That is not true, Senator Kemp, as you know very well.

speech.para: Senator Kemp interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am glad you acknowledge that, because you are a fair person. The NFF does not and cannot represent all sectors of agricultural production, so let me tell you what some of these groups have said. The Australian Fresh Stone Fruit Growers Association reported grave concerns for the effect on their industry. They warned:

speech.para: There is a very real risk of the Federal Government inadvertently steering general community consumption away from fresh fruit and vegetables towards manufactured snack foods because of the proposed change in tax and associated price initiatives.

The government's own package indicates that the GST will result in much higher price increases for fresh food products over junk food. The estimation is somewhere between six and seven per cent—three times that of the economy as a whole.

The Australian Beef Association submitted that the GST would reduce domestic beef sales by nine or 10 per cent. The Dairy Farmers organisation called for milk to be zero rated as one of the staples or necessities of life. A significant submission came from the Mackay Fruit and Vegetable Growers Association, and we hear the same story from the banana sectional group of the Queensland Fruit and Vegetable Growers. The Mackay Fruit and Vegetable Growers Association argues:

There should also be consideration given to the diet of Australians and appropriate exemptions dealt out to those foods which are essential for a person's diet and which lead to a good and healthy life.
Dr Graeme Cole told the inquiry:

Producers will suffer severe economic losses due to reduced returns. The Government which imposed such a tax would be seen to be uncaring of its effect on the poorer section of the community despite protestations that compensation is being considered. The Government would also be seen to be uncaring of the effect on the bulk of the primary producers of Australia.

Increases in prices of fresh fruit, vegetables, meat and cereals—in short, fresh food—will inevitably affect consumption patterns and lead to a reduction in domestic sales. In the short term, this will lead to the loss of 10,600 jobs in food and agricultural industries, the reduction in incomes of rural producers in many sectors, the loss of 2,500 jobs from outer rural regions to the cities and increased compliance costs for farmers. By contrast, zero rating food doubles the long-term economic benefits to agriculture, increases consumption of fresh foods due to lowering of prices and generates extra foods in food and agricultural industries.

However, I do not need to quote simply from the Senate report because, since the Senate report was handed down, we decided that it would be important to go back to those groups that had made submissions to the inquiry and check whether their position was still the same. I want to read to you some of the letters we have received recently which confirm again the position that these groups took at the Senate inquiry. Dairy Farmers called for GST exemption on white milk, and the press release reads:

According to Mr Allan Tooth, the managing director and chief executive officer of the Dairy Farmers Group, the negative impacts associated with imposing a GST on white milk clearly outweigh any immediate financial gains. Dairy Farmers strongly believe that these reasons necessitate the preferential treatment of white milk, especially a GST-free status for white milk. The implications for the dairy industry of the government's proposal for taxation reform cannot be taken lightly, Mr Tooth said.
The Public Health Association of Australia also confirmed what they had said at the inquiry, and I briefly quote:

The Public Health Association of Australia supports the Democrats stance on food and the GST and urges Senator Lees to continue to fight to leave food GST free. Price is one of the most important factors contributing to food choice.
The Australian Consumers Association said:
The Democrats' revamped proposal to exempt fresh food from the GST is a positive way of encouraging healthy eating.
The Australian Council for Health, Physical Education and Recreation said:
The . . . Australian Democrats' stance on GST exemption for healthy basic foods should be applauded. Their stance encourages and provides incentive for Australians to make healthy food choices.
The Australian Beef Association confirmed what they said at the Senate inquiry:

The Australian Beef Association supports the Australian Democrats' fight to exempt fresh food from the GST. ABA documentary evidence supports our belief that a 10 per cent rise in the retail price of beef could reduce consumption of this essential food product by 11.8 per cent.
The Mackay and District Fruit and Vegetable Growers Association confirmed what they said at the Senate inquiry. Most of these letters are dated late April; this one is dated 21 April. They said:

Our association is pleased to support the Australian Democrats' revised tax policy for a zero rating on basic foods. The proposed system, in our view, would return the social equity which would be lost upon a general GST on all foods. Fresh primary produce has faced in excess of a decade of rising costs of production and stagnant or reducing returns. We as producers take extreme pride in supplying our fellow countrymen with the cleanest, greenest produce in the world. Let us not overshadow that pride by making our produce the highest taxed in the world.
One of the small business groups reported on a survey they did:
Fifty-five per cent of the people surveyed believe the Senate has a mandate to modify the tax plan, the latest Yellow Pages small index has found.
It went on to say:
Forty-eight per cent said food should be exempted while 42 per cent said it should not.

The New South Wales Chamber of the Fruit and Vegetable Industries in a long letter to Senator Meg Lees dated 11 May—this is the most up-to-date letter that I have—also supported the stand taken by the Democrats. I will briefly read the introduction:
The New South Wales Chamber is most heartened by the stand you have taken concerning the GST, particularly your position on taxing basic food items such as fresh fruit and vegetables.
In the conclusion to the letter they said:

The best solution is to have fresh fruit and vegetables as basic food items zero-rated or GST-free. This solution would overcome the problems outlined above and will ensure that our industry can continue to provide the Australian community with the best fresh fruit and vegetables in the world at the most affordable prices.

The Democrats, in presenting these amendments to the chamber for consideration, have looked at it from many different perspectives, particularly from my perspective of the effect on the nutrition of people in remote rural and Aboriginal communities and also the effect on jobs in many of the fresh food industries. We are not only putting at risk the health of the people in those Aboriginal and other remote communities but also threatening jobs within many of the industries which supply fresh food for Australian families. I believe for that reason we cannot allow this tax package to pass without these amendments. If we do, then I believe we will be condemning those remote communities to loss of health and nutrition, and we will certainly be causing loss of employment in those fresh food producing industries in Australia which are so critical to the health of this country and so critical to the survival of many rural communities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to briefly follow on from a question I put to the minister yesterday. Although he did not respond formally, I noticed in reading the Hansard that he put in an interjection. I asked why it was that the Prime Minister, John Howard, the Treasurer, Peter Costello, and the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Roderick Kemp, had all supported food not being taxed in 1993. I noticed in the Hansard that the interjection was: `Well, that was because we lost the election,' so you changed tack. I thought that was interesting, and I went and did a little bit of statistical work.

speech.para: In 1993 when, under John Hewson's leadership in the House of Representatives, they put to the electorate a policy that food would not be taxed under a GST—you might like to write this down because they are fascinating figures—John Hewson received 42.3 per cent of the primary vote. In 1998, going to the electorate with a view that food should be taxed under a GST, John Howard's coalition got 39.5 per cent of the primary vote. So in fact you lost 2.8 per cent on your argument because you changed tack on the food issue. In the Senate the figures are even more interesting. In 1993, you got 44.7 per cent of the vote when you went to the community asking for food not to be taxed, and in 1998 you got a miserable 37.7 per cent. You lost seven per cent because you asked for food to be taxed.

I know that the coalition are very clever strategists, so you have to ask yourselves: why would they adopt a policy which they knew would lose them seats and votes? The answer is simple: big business donations. It must have been for financial reasons. It must have been that the big business groups, who are insisting that food be taxed, wagged your tail—otherwise, why would you drop a policy which delivered such a better vote outcome in 1993 than the one delivered in 1998? Why would you lose all those seats unnecessarily?

I thought I should dig up a press release issued by the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer on 18 December 1992. This is what the coalition said, fully supported by John Howard, Peter Costello and Senator Roderick Kemp:

The cost of feeding the family will fall dramatically under a Coalition Government, with basic foods free of GST! . . . There will be no GST on supermarket purchases such as fruit and vegetables, milk products, margarine, bread, eggs, chicken, meat, pure fruit juice, oils and fish.

talk.start.para: —Who said this?

—This is the coalition. Isn't this delicious? In 1992 John Howard, Peter Costello and Roderick Kemp went to the election fully supporting no GST on food. They got a better vote in 1993 than they did in 1998 because they went with that policy. Yet you sacrificed the Australian people, those seats and those members because big business said, `Don't do it, otherwise we won't give you the dough.' What other reason could there be? Why would you sacrifice those poor people?

speech.para: On 13 March 1993 in his article in the Australian John Hewson—a very honest, right-wing leader of the coalition—said:

We will also make sure that families get a fairer deal. With basic food exempted from the GST, the average cost of food will fall. With education and health excluded from the GST, the cost of these services will also fall.

John Hewson, the leader of the coalition at that time, fully supported by John Howard, Peter Costello and Roderick Kemp, in a transcript of a doorstop media conference in Sydney on 18 January 1993, was asked the following question:
. . . can the electorate have any faith that you won't change that plan again?
Mr Hewson replied:

I believe they can because we've put out the detail. We've always opened to listen to people, and we do. We respond. When we hear an argument like the one that was put to us before Christmas about us being unfair, we listened and we excluded food from the GST. So now we can go to this election offering people cheaper food as well as cheaper petrol and cheaper education and cheaper health. But the basic structure of Fightback!, the structural integrity of Fightback!, has been maintained and it will be maintained and it will be implemented.

Yet this government, Mr Howard and Mr Costello do not listen and cannot listen to the people, so they have not changed tack. They argue in complete contrast to their former argument that taxing food would destroy the integrity of their ANTS package in contrast to Fightback.

Minister, I conclude from this that you and your lawyers' government will argue to whatever brief you are given. You know it is unfair, but your brief is to argue that food should be taxed. Formerly in 1993 you and your government recognised that food should not be taxed. You fully supported it. You knew it was fairer, and you are insisting on implementing a miserable, unfair, malicious and mean policy of taxing Australians' basic food.

The essential issue is this: you cannot get compensation if you do not pay tax, because you cannot get the tax cuts if you are not a taxpayer, and you cannot get the benefits of social security if you are not in the social security system. There are well over one million people who fall between the cracks. This is an equity issue, this is a fairness issue, and in 1993 your coalition, you personally, John Howard personally and Peter Costello personally understood that and supported John Hewson's desire not to tax food. You went to the people with it and got a better vote than you got this time.

You have now adopted an unfair policy. Why? Because big business says do it. The churches don't say do it; the charitable organisations don't say do it, the Australian people don't say do it and the polls don't say do it. No-one with a heart says do it, but you want to do it because big business says you must. I believe that is the fundamental moral flaw in your argument. You said yesterday that this is not an equity issue. I am telling you it is a fairness issue and you have changed tack since 1993.

You have always insisted that a GST—a consumption tax—is good and you have held true to that for 20-odd years as a party. I respect that policy position, but you have changed tack on the food issue and I want to know why. I asked that question deliberately yesterday and I have now done the research. You said it was because you lost the election. But you did not lose votes—you gained votes when you had food out. You got a better vote in 1993—a much better vote in the Senate and a better vote in the House of Representatives—when you went to the people and said that you did not want food taxed under a GST. That is all have to say at this time.

talk.start.para: —The Greens totally oppose the GST right across the board, and the argument used by Senator Murray about the indefensibility of having a GST on fresh food also applies to many other items on which a GST will apply and on which the Democrats agree that a GST should apply.

speech.para: A difficulty arises here because, once you start supporting a GST, you run into the problem of where to draw the line. Senator Murray quite correctly says that the government has changed tack on the food issue, but so have the Democrats. The Democrats went to the last election on a policy of exempting food, but since then have changed that policy to exempting fresh food, but not processed food.

The problem still arises for the populace that there is a trend in Australia—right across the income spectrum—towards all of us eating more processed food. This does not just mean food that has been cooked in expensive restaurants, but such things as breakfast, lunch and dinner for families. I accept Senator Murray's asseveration yesterday that it is beyond the Democrats to do modelling on this matter; it is the same with the Greens. Nevertheless, the reality is that Australians, like the rest of the world, are moving more and more towards eating outside their own kitchens. As this process proceeds, the GST formulation that the Democrats are putting forward will catch more and more people paying GST on what they consume—on the food they eat in their ordinary lives—into the future. In other words, the Democrats' formulation is regressive in that it would see the GST place more and more of a burden on the pockets of all Australians—that includes poor Australians as well as wealthy Australians—if the current trend towards eating more processed or cooked foods proceeds, and everything points to that being the case.

The Greens have opposed this GST legislation because of those difficulties. Before the last election we did a lot of work on the GST and its impact on society. In fact, we had already put a year's study into the GST before the election and we went into the election quite firmly opposed to the GST—as did the Labor Party at the time. But, as I said yesterday, a problem has arisen in that the Democrats have said, `We can effectively make the GST consumer-friendly. We can reformulate it so that it will be easier on the average Australian—particularly those on low incomes.' The problem is that I do not think you can do that. The real difficulty with this process is that that allowed the electorate to believe during the election that a nice GST, which was not going to hurt the pocket, could be formulated in the Senate after the election. We clearly see here today that that is not the outcome that we are going to get.

Without reflecting on this place, we are here debating the GST this morning in the absence of the Independent senators. It may be that they are having a cup of tea. I do not know. But, in reality, I would think that the lines are running hot between the Prime Minister's office and other ministerial offices and those of Senator Harradine, if not Senator Colston. The minister might be able to confirm whether that is the case or not—although I think he may be out of the loop, because there are bigger things at stake.

But here we are having a GST formulation at least mooted between entities outside this chamber, which means that whatever agreement is being made out there is going to be the one adopted in this chamber, regardless of the debate we are entering into at the moment. That is the problem for the Democrats, because that was always going to be the case. Having effectively said to the Australian people, `We can make the GST friendly to you,' the reality is that that is not the case today when we are facing an outcome on the GST. We will see what happens to the GST on food. But I want the Democrats to accept the responsibility if we get a package in which the GST is on food but there is some other compensatory measure negotiated with the government by Senator Harradine and Senator Colston. That is an outcome that they will have helped de facto to produce.

The Greens' record will always be clear as having opposed this process from the outset because we could see not only the alternatives but the political dynamic that once you put your toe in the water by saying, `Let us try to have a GST that applies to this or that,' you will ultimately end up with a GST whether you like it or not. The Australian population will then pay the penalty, and what a penalty it will be. It is going to mean an across-the-board tax inevitably increasing on many of the basic necessities of life, while the wealthy and powerful escape the consequences.

There is no debate taking place in here today about the fact that 50 per cent of the multinational corporations in this country pay no tax. If we were debating that, and if that is what the government were proposing, then I, as an Australian Green, would be in full support. I would go to the Prime Minister's office to debate and endorse such a move any day.

talk.start.para: —He can serve you green tea.

—Yes; and we will have a cup of green tea, if necessary, to move towards such an objective. I can tell the Prime Minister that that would be a very popular move with the Australian electorate. It may not be popular with the people who fund the Liberal Party, but it would be popular with 18 million Australians. Today, however, we have got a situation where 18 million Australians are going to pay this new tax impost while those people who fund the Liberal Party are going to continue to find ways of getting around it—and they will find the means of getting around the GST.

speech.para: I have spoken with people in the Taxation Office about this. There is a general belief that the GST is going to end tax avoidance and catch those people who do not pay taxes. That is not the case. Tax systems are inherently able to be circumvented, one way or another, to some degree or other. But the people who best circumvent them are the people who have the money and the smart lawyers. Average people, who are going to pay GST on their cooked food at the local cafe or store are the very people who will be caught, even by the Democrat amendments that we have before us today.

The other problem that is inherent in this for the Democrats is how do you ensure, if you support a GST being brought in on most things, as the Democrats do, that you will not then have a future government moving to extend the GST to the very things that you are keeping clear of it in these amendments, such as fresh food? I would certainly welcome Senator Lees or Senator Murray giving some assurance to the chamber that they know how to stop a future government from putting the GST onto fresh food, even if we did have the legislation altered so that fresh food would be zero rated according to this amendment. You cannot, of course, give such an assurance.

Once you undertake this process, you are on the slippery slope of a future government being able to put the GST on fresh food and also a future government being able to raise the rate of the GST with the states wanting an extra slice further down the line—they would be quite ready and complicit in such a move. That is why the Greens have opposed the GST all the way down the line. All the accolades that Senator Woodley read out from various groups saying that it would be great were milk not GST rated, and so on, apply to a much wider range of primary producers and manufacturers in supporting the Greens' stand, which is similar to that of the ALP.

The one difference is that never, under any circumstances, have we entertained having the real policy of a GST because right from the outset our studies said that it would be an unfair tax and out of date. We ought to be debating more modern alternatives, particularly catching the multinationals. We should be looking at the Greens' alternative which is up with modern European practice of ecotaxes. This is a much better and fairer way of raising revenue, contributing not only to a fairer society in the future but to a much better lifestyle for the average Australian.

talk.start.para: —It is desirable, if at all possible, that we bring this amendment to a vote in the Senate this morning. Therefore, my contribution will be brief. I stated the Labor Party's position on this amendment in my earlier remarks. Simply put, it is that we will be opposing the amendment because we oppose the GST. We do not wish to simply modify a GST which would ensure that a GST comes into being, albeit a slightly less onerous one, then have a tax system in which it is impossible to remove a GST and then be faced with a situation that the GST inevitably will rise, as it has everywhere else. Inevitably, as everywhere else, the base of it will spread further—areas of exemption now before us will be included in future—and the inequities and unfairness, which cannot be sustained and are proven to be false, will get worse as time goes on. You have all heard the Labor Party position on that.

speech.para: We are faced here with a mild dilemma of conscience. We agree with what the Democrats say about removing food and it would make for a fairer tax package if it were out. But the tax package would still be unfair and it is to that principle that we will be directing our attention in not supporting the amendment. At the close of play yesterday, I did ask the minister a series of questions and I would be grateful if the minister were in a position to answer them.

talk.start.para: —I also hope that we are able to bring this to a vote some time this morning. I will be brief in summing up the Democrats' reasons for pursuing this issue. The key point is that, if we are able to remove food from the GST, we remove 75 per cent of the need for compensation. Yesterday we touched on most of what Senator Brown raised, but if I could go back to one point which needs to be clarified: we are not just talking about fresh food; we are talking about a range of processed foods. Indeed, the line is drawn when we come to prepared meals. Virtually everything that is zero rated in the current wholesale sales tax system, plus a few extra things—we have included fresh orange juice, for example, in our zero area—is zero rated in our proposal.

speech.para: The reason we are persisting with this and will continue to persist, even if these amend ments go down today, is that taking food out makes the system far fairer. It will also assist in the creation of some 8,000 to 12,000 jobs—that is from the modelling done which was put before the committee. Senator Woodley has touched on where many of those jobs are to be found and that is out in our agricultural communities. Not taxing food still delivers all of the economic benefits of the GST but, as we have heard time and time again, without the unfairness.

This brings me to some points that Senator Kemp raised yesterday. I find it quite extraordinary that he is still struggling with this issue of equity, claiming that somehow we have not made our point on the equity issue. I ask him: has he not seen all the work put together by what is an historic alliance, a very broad alliance of church groups, charities, community groups and consumer organisations? Those joint statements make it very clear that we are not the only ones saying that the way to get a new tax system that is fair and reasonable is to have one that does not tax essential foods.

This alliance includes Anglicare, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, the Consumers Association, the Council of Social Services, Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, Brotherhood of St Laurence, a range of Salvation Army groups, Secretariat of National Aboriginal and Islander Child Care, Society of St Vincent de Paul, Uniting Church Community Services and the Women's Electoral Lobby. Anyone who suggests that we are somehow not representing a very broad cross-section of concerns in this community simply has not been listening.

If we do not tax food, we will join the 23 out of 27 OECD countries which treat food as a special case—either not taxing it or taxing it at a lower rate. As Senator Kemp has already been through with us, there are a number of countries that do tax it at a lower rate—which completely kills your argument for excluding food on simplicity grounds. These countries actually have a more complex system than the one we are suggesting. Imagine what a GST with 10 per cent on everything but with two or three per cent on food would do to compliance costs for small business compared to zero rating food.

Not taxing food will benefit everybody, contrary to the argument that, because we are paying for the food out option by reducing tax cuts, somehow those who are wealthy will benefit more than those who are at the bottom 40 per cent of the income level because they also buy fresh fruit food and what can be described as the essential foods, the processed foods—all the tinned foods, the dairy products, virtually everything in the frozen food section of the supermarket, short of prepared meals. The argument is that, regardless of income, you buy these goods and somehow the wealthy will benefit from no tax on food, but I remind Senator Kemp yet again that the way we are paying for this is by reducing the tax cuts for the wealthy—in other words, we are taking $30 or $40 from them but giving back $10 because they will not be paying tax on their essential groceries.

One of the things the government has completely overlooked—and if this bill eventually gets through with food in it it will certainly be brought to their attention within the next 18 months—is that if we can take food out we actually get the community on board. Far more Australians will be comfortable about tax reform, about the changes you are making, if we can keep food out and they can see up-front, immediately, once the GST goes in, that their basket of groceries is a little cheaper rather than being significantly more expensive. If you look at the recent polls, 67 per cent of the population support keeping food out of a GST, about another 20 per cent want it in, and the rest do not care. I think the government is running an enormous political risk pressing ahead with this obsession for keeping food in on the grounds of simplicity when it has undermined that argument by taking out health and education in particular.

In short, rather than unravelling the tax package, our amendments will make it more attractive, more jobs friendly, fairer and more robust. I recommend that the government starts listening not just to the Democrats but to those in the community who want food left out of the new tax system.

talk.start.para: —I will respond to the range of comments that have been made unless there is anyone else who wishes to add to the debate. I am delighted that we all feel that this debate must now hopefully be brought to an end. We have had a very good debate in the chamber. It has lasted some hours. The overall debate on the bill is now reaching over 40 hours and already it is one of the most lengthy—
—If you keep reminding us, we'll keep going.

—I just make the point and I think it is an important point. I am making the point that a lot of the issues in this bill have been very extensively canvassed. I think it is an important point to make and no-one is saying that this is being rushed through—in fact, no-one could possibly argue that this is being rushed through, I would think.

speech.para: I turn to some of the comments that have been made, some of which overlap. In Senator Woodley's contribution he argued, among other things, that we should zero rate food because this is world's best practice. I would have to say that practically none of the evidence given to the committee suggests that this is world's best practice. All the expert modellers that were brought before the committee, including those chosen by the non-government parties, indicated that food should not be zero rated. It is one thing to have a committee—and I think it is important that we listen to the evidence that went before that committee—but the government takes considerable comfort from the fact that the overwhelming weight of evidence before that committee from the experts called by all parties supported, by and large, the government's position that world's best practice in effect meant that you would not zero rate food.

I always listen to Senator Murray with great interest. He always seeks to make a serious contribution but I would have to say, Senator Murray, that that was one of your less serious contributions. It was a bit of a filibuster, I think one could say. But there was a serious point raised that I want to tackle. It is not your usual style to talk in this manner—that somehow we had adopted this policy because of pressure from big business or whatever. I do not think you believe that. The explanation for why this policy was adopted is that after a lot of intensive study and a lot of looking around to see what happened elsewhere in the world we came to the conclusion that this was world's best practice, we came to the conclusion that we would establish a tax system which would set a new standard. So we looked at the experience of other countries, we looked at the problems in other countries, and we developed a tax system which we believe has taken note of the experience elsewhere in the world and has made sure that Australians have a world-class tax system.

In this debate we can all raise our voices and allege that people have not addressed particular issues, but I repeat, Senator Lees, that I do not think the Democrats in their contributions have really been prepared to tackle the equity position and argue it strongly. The evidence that was given to the committee indicated that what you were doing in attempting to zero rate food was a very blunt instrument indeed. It indicated that a lot of the benefits you are seeking for lower income people would flow to people on higher incomes. These were committees the Democrats were very keen to establish and the Democrats called a lot of people before them. The overwhelming expert opinion was that, if you were concerned about the issues of equity and you wanted to argue those issues, zero rating food was not the way to go. That evidence has been strongly ignored. A widely recognised world-class expert, Professor Cnossen, whose name has come up in this debate from time to time, indicated:

Zero-rating food does little in alleviating the plight of the poor. In New Zealand it was estimated that households with the lowest 20 per cent of income would receive only 15 per cent of the aggregate benefit of a zero rate on food. The other 80 per cent of households not considered to be poor would receive 85 per cent of the benefit.

Similarly, in the US, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that zero rating food would reduce the regressivity of a federal VAT by only 18 per cent. I am pointing out to you that the equity issue is an important one. We believe that the government has addressed very clearly the equity issue and we have looked at the experience elsewhere in the world. What you are proposing here is not the way to address the equity issue. As I said, we are supported by the evidence that was continually led before the committees which inquired into this particular issue.

To Senator Murray I would say that a better explanation of why the government has adopted this approach is that we believe that we have established a tax package which is fair and equitable and which provides the compensation which is required. We rely on the evidence that was led before the committee by many experts.

Senator Brown has made some interesting observations. I do not agree with Senator Brown's general position but I do agree with him—and he argued this yesterday and touched on it today—that there is great complexity being brought about as a result of the amendments now before us from the Democrats. We ran through some of the peculiarities which this would produce, and I do not want to add too much to what Senator Brown said to that because, to the extent that he was arguing the complexity issue, in general he was broadly correct.

There are many hundreds of examples which would show that. For example, fillet steak would be GST free, but frozen hamburgers would be taxable under this amendment. I am not sure what the equity argument is there, but it is not one that I feel persuaded by. Fresh crayfish will be GST free, but frozen fish fingers will be taxable under the Democrat proposal. I am not sure where the equity argument lies there, either, and we can produce hundreds of examples like this.

So there is an equity argument for why we should oppose what the Democrats are doing and there is a complexity argument, which has not been touched on broadly in this particular part of the debate but which I think is well known. In terms of creating a world-class tax system, this is what we believe we are achieving with the proposal which we have put before the chamber.

I have listened carefully to the debate. The relentless assertion on the equity issue does not mean that the proposal before us is equitable, and I do not believe that that issue has been effectively addressed by the Democrats, nor have the arguments which have been run by a wide range of experts on this particular issue been addressed.

I think that broadly covers it. There were some issues raised by Senator Peter Cook, who asked me for a response to his questions. As Senator Cook is here now, I shall respond to them. The general principle of the government's tax reform package is that food is taxable.

There are a limited number of occasions when food is GST free. These occasions mainly involve situations where food is provided as part of a GST free service. These include, as I said yesterday, food provided to hospital patients, food provided to nursing home residents receiving GST-free care, food provided incidentally as part of a GST-free child-care service. Food may be also GST free if the supply of food qualifies as a non-commercial supply by a charity. For example, the supply of food below 50 per cent of market value at a soup kitchen would be GST free, and I think we would all support that.

Food purchased by a business will not be GST free but will be taxable, but that business will be entitled to an input tax credit, provided it is a genuine business expense. This is the same principle, Senator Cook, that applies at the moment to income tax deductibility. The government is not changing the rules for income tax deductibility. Further, division 69 of the GST bill links the allowance of input tax credits to whether an item can be deducted for income tax purposes.

There were a number of questions you put to me. One was this: `Would you agree that passengers on an inbound international flight get their food GST free?' Passengers on an international airline flight purchase a GST-free service that includes food as part of that service. This particular issue does not raise compliance costs issues of general food exemption, since determining whether a flight is international is relatively straightforward for the small number of businesses involved.

Then you raised the issue of owners of greyhounds and horses and of farm animals and any purchases there. All the food in relation to those would be taxable. Business will be entitled to business tax credits to the extent that the food is a genuine business expense. We are well aware how that occurs under the current tax law, and this is very similar to the current income tax treatment of deductibility.

There are a number of other issues you raised. We do not believe there is any additional complexity as a result of what we have proposed. Under the current system, business will have to differentiate between business related and therefore deductible expenses and non-business related expenses. You asked whether it is true that a business person attending a business convention on, say, the Gold Coast and claiming the business convention as an input to their production will have their air fares, their accommodation and the food they eat while they are there GST free. The answer to that, Senator Cook, is no. The items will be taxable. A business may be entitled to input tax credits for genuine business expenses. This is the same principle as currently applies for income tax deductibility.

You were worried about the complexity if, say, you were a lawyer attending a legal conference on the Gold Coast. You said you would not pay GST on your air fares or your hotel and you damn sure would not pay GST on the food—if I quote you accurately, Senator Cook. You ask whether that is not a degree of complexity. I have answered the general issue in relation to food, and I have said in my response to the general point you made on complexity that there is no additional complexity for the business above that required for income tax or FBT. You asked whether this was hidden in the package, and I indicated to you that nothing is hidden. The bill is quite explicit in division 69 that there is a link between the ability to claim input tax credits and income tax deductibility.

I think that responds to the general points you raised. I have covered the questions which were raised earlier in the debate by a wide range of speakers. We have had a long debate on this food issue, and the government will not be supporting the amendment which has been moved by the Democrats.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Minister, for answering my questions as you have. But I think your answers leave more questions than have in fact been answered. As I understood you—correct me if I am wrong—you said in part of your answer that input tax credits are provided if it is a business expense. If that is what you are saying, it might save time if you could just indicate to me that that is right.
—People would be entitled to an input tax credit if it is a genuine business expense.
—If I am in the business of racing greyhounds, the food for my dogs is an input to my business. In that case, is that food GST free?

—Let me take you back to the current law. If you are a greyhound owner as a business and you purchase the food as a business expense for the greyhounds, under the current system, which you support, you are able to claim that, if it is a genuine business expense, as a tax deduction. But if you, Peter Cook, as a private person purchase food, you, Peter Cook, are not entitled to claim that as a tax deduction. This occurs under the current law which the Labor Party supports and which we inherited from the Labor Party. So the principle there is that, for a greyhound owner and a genuine business racing greyhounds, genuine business expenses to run that business are tax deductible under your system. Therefore, if food is a genuine business expense under the current system, that is tax deductible. But Peter Cook purchasing his food down at the local shop is not entitled to a tax deduction on that food.

speech.para: That is the principle, and it is a principle which has been strongly endorsed, I would have thought, by the Labor Party and others. This was part of tax law, I suspect, for a very long period of time and was not attempted to be changed. In fact, there were complexities brought into the law, as you are aware, with FBT—

talk.start.para: —Which you opposed.

—Which we have been able to amend and deal with. Nonetheless, it is complex. Anyone understands the complexities of FBT arrangements. But that is the principle, and it is a principle which is deeply embedded in the income tax system at this present time.

—That is not quite the question I asked. You actually answered three different questions. Let me try and be more precise. Before I do, let me just say that this exchange will be helped a lot if the propaganda that you wish to use to tell everyone what the Labor Party position is were excluded from your answers, with respect, Minister. You tell us that we defend the existing tax system, that it is our system. That is a propaganda point. We came to the last election with a whole program of tax reform. That is our system. It is change to the present system and it is tax reform without a GST. But you want everyone to think that we have no policies on tax changes, so you go around saying that. Let us just get the propaganda out of the way and concentrate on the issue. I was not asking you a question on whether I, Peter Cook, or you, Roderick Kemp, a greyhound racing company, bought food that the owners consumed. If they bought food that the dogs consumed, that is an input to their business, is it not, and the food those dogs consume is not GSTable. That is the straightforward question, that it is not GSTable. Is that right?

—When the food is purchased it is taxable, so there is a GST paid on that food. If it is a genuine business expense, as with all genuine business expenses the business can claim an input tax credit. But the food is taxable. As I said, the analogy is exactly the same at the moment where someone in a genuine business—say, someone who runs greyhounds—has to purchase food for the business. If he purchases food for the business, that is an income tax deduction. That is exactly the principle which is embed ded in the current tax system. So he is able to claim that as an income tax deduction, but when you, Peter Cook, go and purchase food—

speech.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —But I am making the point—and it is quite an important point—so that it will be well understood that when you purchase food, despite the fact you are the greyhound owner, the food that you purchase is not income tax deductible because it is not part of a business expense; it is a private expense.

—I was not arguing that point. So what you are saying to me, if I can just get it clear, is that Roderick Kemp Greyhound Racing Co. purchases food for its greyhounds, it pays a GST under your bill on that food and then it claims back the value of that GST from the Commissioner of Taxation as an input to its production and the tax commissioner remits the GST value on that food to Roderick Kemp Greyhound Racing Co. Is that right?
—I think that is a fair summary. That is the general flow. Of course it is slightly more detailed because you file a consolidated form and all that, but in general the principle is right.
—So if you order a bit of Bollinger for your greyhound, you get it back.
—Or some fillet steak.

—That is an interesting interjection because it does mean that if Roderick Kemp Greyhound Racing Co. buys fillet steak for its greyhounds on the night of the race and any of the owners eat the leftover fillet steak they have to run down to the butcher and pay a GST on it. But that is another matter.

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You are talking about degrees of complexity. You are attacking the Democrats on degrees of complexity. There is a great deal of complexity in your own bill. Let me go to another example, having established that. I happen to be a supporter of the West Coast Eagles football team.
—Don't apologise.
—I am not apologising; I am quite proud of it.
—This is more for the confessional, I think, than the chamber.

—No. I know you are a supporter of Carlton, but anyway let us not get AFL rivalries into this debate because we will be here until the cows come home. Of course the food the cows eat when they do come home is GST free, but that is not the matter.
—Yes, but is the manure GST free?

—That is a load of horse—look, I will not get into that argument. This is a team of professional footballers who have a dietary consultant. The business of professional sportspersons in this case is one in which they earn money because of their sporting prowess and ability and they are required by this team, under the advice of the dietary consultant, to eat particular food, carbohydrates, before a match. Indeed, for the four days leading up to the match they have a graph of the consumption of the carbohydrates that they have to take to give them energy on the day, and if they do not do it they are in breach of the rules of the club and of their contract. These are professional sportspeople. My question is: is the food that they consume in their business of being a professional sportsperson able to be, as in the case of the greyhounds, rebated by tax; that is to say, they end up at the end of the cycle not having to pay GST on their food? Is that the case if you are in the business of being a professional sportsperson with particular dietary requirements in order to pursue your sport?

—I have received some rapid advice. As I have indicated, the test is whether the particular expense is currently deductible. Is it deductible under the current law? If the expense is, that is the test which is applied here. I am advised by my tax officers that in fact there have been some rulings on similar cases. I do not think this is the place to give tax rulings on particular cases, but there have been tax rulings on similar issues and they are not tax deductible.

—So professional sportspersons under contract to a professional sporting club who, in terms of their contract with their club, are required to, in the conduct of their profession, consume certain foods cannot claim an input tax deduction on the GST. Is that what you are saying?

—They cannot claim under the current arrangements, as I understand it, and I am being slightly cautious here because I do not want to be giving rulings, but perhaps people would accept the generality of what I am saying in relation to this. My understanding is that there have been similar cases in which the Commissioner of Taxation has issued rulings. The rulings of the tax commissioner in like cases, as I understand, are that they are not tax deductible as a business expense. So under the current law in the case you quoted—where someone is required, as part of their sport, to consume a certain food—that is not deductible. This is in contrast with the current system where we dealt with the issue of the inputs to a greyhound racing business that is being run. So, in relation to the sportsman, it is not regarded as an expense which is deductible and, therefore, because we link deductibility under the GST to the current tax law, the situation is the same.
—So what you are saying is the dog gets it but the sportsman does not. Is that right?

—No. What I am saying is that, at present, under the law which was left to us, the greyhound racing business gets deductibility under the current law but the sportsman does not. We are, in a sense, giving a mirror image of that. That is exactly the principle. This is not a principle. This is a principle which you and your colleagues were very happy with under the law, which you said is not your policy, although I have to say that I was interested in your comments on what your policy is because Senator Sherry made a comment yesterday—
—Oh, look.
—He did.
—Do you want to be here all morning?
—No, I do not. You said to me that I am not speak about your policy. Senator Sherry said:

speech.para: I am certainly not privy to advance copies of any tax policy; it does not exist at the present time.
That is what Senator Sherry said about the Labor Party yesterday.

talk.start.para: —Hooray for you, Minister, that is a debating point! You know what our policy is; we put it to the Australian people at the last election. So the dog gets it but the sportsperson does not, and you defend that on the basis that that is the existing law. But of course your tax changes, the whole 27 bills we have under consideration, are to change the existing law, and if you do not wish to change that then you accept that as a principle of your tax system.
—Do you accept it as a principle of yours?

—Under our tax system there is no GST, Minister. If you want to get into an argument about that: you are imposing a GST; there is a lot of food that is not subject to tax—which is the point the Democrats have been making for the last couple of days; I thought it would have reached you by now—and if this goes through there will be a lot of food which will be taxed for the first time. You argue that you cannot do a deal with the Democrats on the basis of complexity; I am just pointing out some of the complexities in your system.

speech.para: Let me move on, having heard what you have said—that the dog gets it but the sports person does not, even though it is a requirement of their profession in this case. In answer to the question you said that input tax credits are provided if it is a business expense. So, if I am a merchant banker and I live in Perth and I fly to Sydney to conduct my business in organising a takeover of a company in Sydney, is the cost that I incur for the airfare, the hotel accommodation and the food I consume an input to my business or is it not?

talk.start.para: —The general principle applies: are they deductible now? If Senator Peter Cook as a private person flies from Perth to Sydney, he cannot claim those expenses; they are private expenses. If Peter Cook, merchant banker, flies to Sydney and has general business expenses and they are deductible under the current law, the general principle of course is that they are taxable. But, if they are deductible under the current law, input tax credits can be claimed. So that is the linkage. The issue in relation to meals, as I understand it from advice from the Australian Taxation Office, is:

speech.para: Meal expenses are deductible for employees if they are incurred in relation to travel they are required to undertake to perform their jobs. Such expenditure is generally matched by travel allowances paid to them by their employers.

The Commissioner of Taxation has issued a Taxation Ruling . . . which excepts deduction claims based on travel allowances from substantiation requirements provided they do not exceed reasonable levels.
So, as I said, it is the same principle that is applied under the current system.

talk.start.para: —A principle you incorporate in your tax system, which has to be the point. So the answer you have just given is—and correct me if I am wrong—that if I go from Perth to Adelaide to visit my mother, as a private citizen, I pay GST on my airfare, on my accommodation and on the food I consume, but if I am a merchant banker and I fly to Adelaide for business I do not pay GST on my airfare, I do not pay GST on my accommodation and, to quote myself from yesterday, I sure as hell do not pay GST on the food I consume because that is a business input. That is correct, isn't it, Minister?
—You pay GST, but if it is a genuine business expense you get a credit. That is the principle.

—I get a credit—which means it is refunded. So, in effect, I pay it up-front and get it back from the tax commissioner. So at the end of the transaction I have not paid the GST; that is my point. That is if I am a merchant banker. Let me try you with another example, and this time I am a lawyer. The Law Council of Australia is having a legal convention on the Gold Coast. Perhaps I am a family lawyer and the theme of the law convention is family law. Perhaps there are some visiting international experts in jurisprudence on family law coming to address this convention. As a lawyer, this is front and centre professional information and background to my capacity to be successful. I fly to the convention, I participate in it and I fly home. I am working within my profession and increasing my skills and knowledge of my profession. In those circumstances are my airfares, my accommodation or my food GSTable? If your answer is, `Of course they are, but you claim it back and then you will get it refunded,' that means to me as a lay person that, after all of this slipping and sliding, I do not pay GST. When I ask you whether it is it GSTable, of course I pay GST up-front and of course I claim it back as a business cost to my practice, and I guess the question is: does the Commissioner of Taxation then refund my GST costs?

—You are right, it is taxable. The test is: is it a genuine business expense? If it meets that test of a genuine business expense—and that is well established under current law—you are entitled to claim an input tax credit, and the principle is that that is refunded to you.

—My understanding of the current business law is that, in those circumstances, I can claim it back as a business expense if I am a lawyer attending a conference dealing with matters that are pertinent to my profession. That is true, isn't it, Minister?

—I am not a lawyer, and I do not go to legal conferences, so I have no direct personal knowledge of this. The general principle is that if it is a genuine business expense the GST will be paid on the expenses. As I said, the test is: is it deductible under the current law? If it is deductible under the current law, you can claim an input tax credit. I have answered that a couple of times.

—I know you are not a lawyer, and I respect your confession that you are not a lawyer, but you are here as the Assistant Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia answering questions on a tax bill that the government says is the great adventure for Australia in taxation and is the most revolutionary change in tax law ever. Sitting alongside you are six of the best advisers that Treasury, the Taxation Office and Mr Costello can provide you with. In that case, Minister, you are the qualified person to answer the question. My question again is: under the existing arrangements—which you use to defend your current proposal—isn't it true that in the example I have quoted it is a business expense for my professional practice for me as a lawyer to go to that conference, to be accommodated at that conference and for the meals I have at that conference and that I can deduct those expenses? If it is, I can deduct the GST too, can't I?

—Yes, we have been through that. That is the case. I repeat: the general expenses that you have mentioned are taxable—if I recall them correctly—and the GST is paid on them. These amendments relate to housing issues. Whilst a lot of the attention to date in relation to the tax package has been on food, the Democrats have been at pains to point out many of the other problems and inadequacies of the government's tax package as it exists. Certainly the issue of housing is a fundamental and crucial one—often referred to as part of the necessities of life, quite reasonably—and one that is significantly affected, potentially very negatively, by aspects of this tax package. There are a number of different aspects to it, particularly in relation to the potential impact on the costs of public housing, on private rental, on home ownership costs, et cetera. These particular amendments deal specifically with the home purchasing costs for home buyers. They seek to establish a GST new home rebate, which would replace the First Home Owners Scheme, to compensate purchasers of new housing for the impact of the GST.

The amendments are very important. As I have just outlined, housing is an important issue. It was one of the terms of reference of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee on which I represented the Democrats. That committee received a lot of very worthwhile evidence about matters relating to housing. Without trying to sound churlish, I would have to say that the government was one of the areas from which we did not get much information about the impacts of the GST on housing. That was a great concern and a disappointment to me and to the Democrats.

These amendments that I have just moved on behalf of the Democrats are very important and have been developed in close consultation with the Housing Industry Association. They also broadly pick up concerns of other groups about the impact of the GST on housing, including the Urban Development Institute, National Shelter, ACOSS and various tenant organisations. The amendments represent a real win-win solution for home buyers and for renters. The amendments significantly reduce the cost of housing under a GST, but without adding to the cost of the tax package as a whole. I should emphasise that: they will not add to the cost of the tax package as a whole. They are economically responsible, which is something the Democrats have ensured in our approach to this tax package. They are constructive attempts to improve what is clearly a flaw in the tax package. For that reason, I do hope that the Senate gives them serious consideration.

The First Home Owners Scheme, which will cost around $800 million, provides a grant of $7,000 to first home buyers. This is in theory—from the explanations of the government—to compensate them for the higher cost of housing due to a GST. But as information provided to the Senate committee demonstrated, the vast bulk of the $800 million will be in windfall gains to first home buyers rather than compensation for the GST. This is because around 85 per cent of first home buyers are buying established homes rather than new homes. The GST will barely affect the price of existing homes as the cost of building these homes was obviously pre-GST.

The residential housing sector, which employs around 300,000 people, will also be adversely affected by a GST. Murphy and Monash modelling forecast a 2½ per cent decline in housing investment. Murphy has suggested that the price of house construction will rise around six per cent and the price of a house and land package by about five per cent. Employment in housing is forecast to fall by 8,000 jobs, partly offset by a 7,000 job gain in commercial construction. Again, it is important to emphasise not only the issues of fairness and equity that the Democrats have spoken about often but also the issue of employment. The six per cent rise in house prices compares with the 4.7 per cent increase forecast by Treasury—another area where Treasury's forecasts seemed to be lower than everybody else's. The Housing Industry Association, HIA, estimates that the price of new homes will rise by eight per cent on the introduction of a GST, falling to five per cent in the longer term.

Rents will also rise in the longer term as the higher cost of building flows through to rents. Modelling by Econtech suggests that rents will rise by three to four per cent in the longer term. Other bodies giving evidence to the Senate inquiry suggested that the rise in rents could be even higher—as much as eight to 12 per cent. I suggest that they are figures that should be taken quite seriously. The rental market is a completely different market to the home owners market, and it various enormously from city to city, from city to the country, from regional to capital cities and, indeed, within cities.

Whilst there is obviously some relationship between the cost of rents and the cost of purchasing housing, it is simplistic in the extreme to automatically draw precise parallels between the cost of housing in a particular spot and the cost of private rental; similarly, to use a universal across-the-board formula to suggest that, if the cost of housing goes up by three per cent, four per cent or whatever, the cost of private rentals flowing on over time will similarly be three or four per cent higher. There is an enormous variation. I am sure all senators would be aware of examples in different parts of Australia. I know that in my own home state of Queensland, in some of the regional towns and coastal towns, housing is reasonably cheap to purchase, but the availability of housing for rental is extremely minimal and therefore the rents are extremely high. Obviously that is dominated by, and dictated to, market forces, and those market forces do not just rely on simple economic modelling flow-on calculations. There is a lot more dynamic than that.

I think the reality of potential rent increases needs to be taken seriously. Some of these figures that were suggested as potential rent increases in some parts of the country—not a universal across-the-board increase, but from eight to 12 per cent in some parts of the country—come from organisations which specialise in housing issues and look at them on a day-to-day basis. It is the focus of their activities. They are people that know what they are talking about.

Without being too critical of the government department, the impression I got from evidence the officers from the relevant government department gave to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee would suggest that not quite so much thought had gone into considering all the potential flow-on effects and potential consequences. Rents may rise not just because of higher building costs. Part of the increase would flow from higher demand for rental properties, as potential home buyers are forced to defer decisions and as landlords reduce investments in response to higher prices and lower returns.

These sorts of figures relating to the potential rise in rents are of great concern to the Democrats. After food the next biggest cost item for low income earners is housing. It is 19.3 per cent of the household spending for the bottom quintile. That four per cent rise in rental costs—even if it is as low as four per cent—will hit that sector hard. The rise in rental assistance will never provide full compensation, as rental assistance is paid to only about half of social security beneficiaries and, in any event, it only goes up to, at most, 75 per cent of the price difference. It will not affect all those people and people in rental are, broadly speaking, in the lower socioeconomic bracket.

The government's First Home Buyer Scheme not only compensates 85 per cent of home buyers who do not need compensation or need less compensation but also does not compensate the millions of private sector entrants facing real increases because of the GST. It is a blunt, poorly targeted giveaway that fails, on the basic test of value for money, in alleviating the cost impact of the GST on housing. The Democrats' proposed GST new home rebate addresses these problems. The scheme will provide a 50 per cent rebate on the actual GST paid on new housing, rising to 100 per cent for first home buyers. The rebate will also apply to new housing for rental purposes and to major renovations of rental properties to ensure that funds are spent on maintaining rental properties in a reason able condition for the people that pay the rent on them.

The Housing Industry Association commissioned modelling from Econtech on the price impact of replacing the First Home Buyers Scheme with a GST compensation scheme at the same fiscal cost. They recommended a rearranging of the First Home Buyers Scheme into a rebate scheme because, they argued, around $600 million of the $830 million earmarked for the current scheme would be used to support the purchase of GST-free homes. That was provided in evidence submitted to the committee by the HIA. By converting the scheme into a partial GST stamp duty rebate scheme, at a cost of only an additional $90 million, much of the negative effect on housing is reversed.

Econtech's modelling of the effect of the HIA compensation proposal provided some quite significant figures. The proposal eliminates three-quarters of the negative impact on residential building activity, 60 per cent of the job losses, 60 per cent of the price effects and 90 per cent of the predicted increase in rents. Further, it would mean a long-term CPI decrease of 0.7 per cent. It is worth remembering that Murphy also found that zero rating of food—not that we want to revisit the food debate just now—would reduce the long-term CPI from 0.8 per cent to negative 0.5 per cent. So that CPI increase will reduce the effect on prices even further.

The model proposed by the Democrats in these amendments is structured slightly differently from the proposal used in the HIA modelling, but the overall economic effect is similar and the modelling results are unlikely to be substantially different. That, combined with zero rating of food, would mean that we would eliminate the price effect of 43 per cent of the spending on food and rent by low income earners.

Once you add in our proposals to broaden the health exemption, and zero rate public transport and books, around 60 per cent of the spending of low income earners would be picked up by concessional GST treatment, with zero or indeed negative price effects. That is a great outcome for low income earners, and these amendments are an important part of that strategy.
