—I think it would be worth while if I outlined in more detail the specific technical aspects of the amendment which may assist senators in terms of how it will actually operate in practice. Of course, we outlined the rationale, the justification and the benefits; but I think the technical operations are important. This GST new home rebate will apply when new homes are bought from builders operating under the Australian business number system; to new homes utilised for owner occupancy; for private and public rental accommodation; and also to new homes being a single dwelling, semi-detached house, apartment or transportable home. So first home buyers will be eligible for a GST new home rebate of up to $12,000 paid on the purchase of a new home, including land. Other purchasers of a new home, including public housing authorities, will qualify for a maximum rebate of $6,000. I think it is important not to forget the potential impact of this package on public housing authorities and their ability to stretch their budgets to meet the very significant and important areas of public housing need.

speech.para: Under the amendments, `purchase price' means the price paid to the builder for the house and land before the GST is calculated and does not include any associated legal fees or agents fees. Sales of new homes erected on existing land, new homes built to replace previously demolished homes on the same land, and substantially renovated homes should be treated in the same way as sales of new housing. `Substantial renovation' means that all or substantially all of the dwelling, except the foundations, external walls, interior supporting walls, floor, roof and staircases, are removed or replaced. New and amended definitions have been developed for the dictionary in division 195 to achieve this.

For example, a builder in the renovation business purchases an established dwelling upon which there is no GST on the purchase price. He completely guts and replaces the interior with new walls, ceilings, floors, kitchen, wiring and plumbing. The substantially renovated home, when sold, should be, for GST purposes, treated like a new home. The purchaser will be entitled to claim the GST new housing rebate under this example.

Other renovations or improvements to a home, such as replacing a kitchen or building an addition, are not considered substantial renovations. If GST has been paid on the acquisition of the land, a rebate can be claimed only after a contract for a new dwelling on the land has been entered into. Where land has been purchased prior to 1 July 2000 or the commencement of the GST, a rebate will not be payable on the purchase price of the land.

An application for the GST new housing rebate must be made jointly by the purchaser and the builder. The rebate form would be available from builders, real estate agents, financial institutions and the Taxation Office. Whilst the purchaser must apply for the GST rebate, the purchaser can assign the right to receive the rebate to the builder selling the new home. This assignment allows the builder to pass the benefit of the rebate on to the purchaser at the time of sale and reduce up-front financing requirements. If the rebate is not paid or credited by the builder, the purchaser has up to two years under these amendments, from the date of completion of the project, to claim the rebate directly from the Taxation Office.

Referring specifically to amendments Nos 6 and 10, which deal with the major renovations of rental accommodation rebate, under the GST leased residential premises are input taxed. Landlords pay GST on the goods and services they acquire, such as repairs and maintenance, but cannot claim an input tax credit for that GST. There is no GST charged on rents. So landlords therefore face a financial disincentive to perform needed renovations, alterations, additions or repairs to their rental properties. Certainly, from my experience over a number of years working on housing issues and tenancy issues—in particular in Queensland—ensuring that landlords actually maintain properties in a condition fit for human habitation is unfortunately, in some circumstances, already difficult enough to achieve. Providing extra financial disincentives for them to do that is something the Democrats are greatly concerned about. So major renovations or improvements will be eligible for a GST rebate where a dwelling is leased or intended to be leased as a rental property. Rental property owners—public and private—will be eligible for a GST rebate of 50 per cent of the contract price of home renovations and improvements where the contract value exceeds $10,000 and the contract is with a builder registered under the Australian business number system.

I think that outlines the technical operation of the Democrats range of amendments in relation to housing. Again, I wish to emphas ise how important this area is for the potential impact of the tax package. As I said at the start of my contribution, there has been a lot of focus on the issue of food. Other issues—such as housing—which are just as important have not received as much public attention. Perhaps this is partly because, in many ways, housing is more complex than food. The way the housing and rental markets work is a bit mysterious for many people. But clearly the evidence provided to the Senate community affairs committee by organisations such as the Housing Industry Association and the New South Wales Federation of Housing Associations which work and deal with housing issues on a daily basis show that this is an area where there will be significant negative impacts if improvements such as those suggested under these Democrat amendments are not made.

There is a great deal of confusion in the community about the impact on housing in all its various forms. The housing sector is complex and, of course, when people talk about the housing market they are talking about several markets of very different natures. There is the new housing market, the second-hand market, the rental property market, public housing, community housing, cooperative housing and mobile homes, among others. The evidence provided to the committee of inquiry certainly gave me a lot of concern that there had not been an adequate amount of work done prior to the formulation of this package in determining exactly how the GST and the associated tax reforms will impact upon all these sectors of the housing market. That situation makes it hard to take on face value the government's sweeping statements that no group in the community will be worse off. Clearly, work had not been done on determining the potential impact on all of these many, very different parts of what is described by the single label of `the housing market'.

Generalisations about the housing market often mean very little. As with many other issues that have come up in this tax debate, nationwide averages might make sense to economists and provide handy general benchmarks, but they are often not terribly mean ingful or helpful to individuals who fall a long way above or below those averages. So those arguments and those issues apply just as much, if not more so, to issues relating to housing as they do to issues such as food, which we have previously debated.

talk.start.para: —The Democrat amendments would replace the First Home Owners Scheme. The government does not agree with these amendments. The scheme does not differentiate between purchasers of new and established houses. It will fully compensate first home buyers for the increase in the price of new homes with a construction value, excluding land, of up to $150,000. speech.para: The amendments would transform the government's First Home Owners Scheme from a scheme aimed at compensating those without any existing housing equity into a scheme aimed at benefiting the building industry. Indeed, the Democrat amendments would lead to a fall in the cost of buying a house, as their scheme gives a full rebate. The Democrat amendments make no allowance at all for the significant industry cost reductions that would flow to the building industry. The Democrat amendments would also be biased against first home buyers who wish to move into established areas such as inner cities.

To conceptualise it, there are significant adverse effects as a result of the amendments which Senator Bartlett has moved. The amendments would disadvantage first home buyers who wish to purchase an established home rather than construct a new home. This shift in emphasis may preclude many first home owners from purchasing the home most suited to their needs and budget, and deter many new entrants to the housing market. The amendments could have an adverse effect on the market for established dwellings, with flow-on effects to the rest of the building market.

In effect, the Democrat amendments would redirect assistance away from first home buyers, as I said, towards purchasers of new homes and major renovations. Many of these people may already own homes and would also benefit from any GST induced rise in house values. So we are opposed to these amendments.

As I think I said earlier, the rebate is based on the initial purchase price without legal fees and the GST section of the price, so that is a component of calculating that available amount.

—I do not have my adviser next to me. I might say that I accept that it is a bit more difficult for Senator Bartlett, because the Democrats are not placed physically to receive advice readily from their advisers. But I am frankly not able to follow your explanation, nor are our advisers. We are somewhat confused about subclause (6). We do not believe that the explanation you have given so far is adequate in enabling us to reach an understanding of what exactly the meaning of subclause (6) is.

speech.para: I would like to make a few general comments about the block of amendments we are considering at this stage. The block of amendments moved by the Democrats go to housing ownership renovations. What is obviously important to note about the effect of a goods and services tax is that it represents a new barrier to home ownership in this country. The price of housing and housing related other property services goes up as a result of a goods and services tax. Senator Margetts rightly pointed out in her earlier contribution that housing—and there is obviously an associated flow-on to rental increases—is one of the necessities of life. A roof over your head, food, clothing and power are all part of the necessities of life. The goods and services tax represents a new and additional barrier to home ownership in this country, to the great Australian dream of owning your own home. This is a further example of the unfair impact of the goods and services tax on Australians.

Some other aspects of this cause the Labor Party concern. The government estimated that the initial price impact of a GST would be 1.9 per cent—10 per cent GST but they claim that the price impact would be 1.9 per cent. However, this is the old pea and thimble trick. They excluded from that 1.9 per cent general price increase the impact of housing prices and the impact of the increase in tobacco. If you include those two areas, the increase in prices as a result of a GST is at least 3.1 per cent. There are other issues that are not relevant to this debate.

I highlight that point to the Senate, because it is part of the con job that the current Liberal government and Senator Kemp have been involved in in attempting to convince people that the goods and services tax is good for Australians when it is clearly not. As I mentioned earlier, a rise in housing prices obviously has a flow-on effect to rents, because if the cost to purchase a property increases—as it will under a GST—rents will obviously rise. What I am sure will occur is that existing owners of property will also increase rents—general rents will go up as a consequence of a GST, even for those people who currently own property.

We do not accept the government's figures that are outlined in the ANTS package. The claim is made that for the ownership of dwellings—I think it is 77.1 in the tables—there will be a price increase of 2.3 per cent and that for other property services the price increase will be 6.7 per cent. Labor believes that is an underestimation. I think Senator Bartlett did refer in his earlier comments to other studies that have been carried out by other modellers about the price impact on housing and associated property services. We believe these figures again have been massaged and deliberately minimised to understate the impact of a GST on the housing and associated residential services and rentals sectors.

On the question that I asked Senator Kemp: the government, in an attempt to massage this con job on the Australian people, has said that it is going to provide a $7,000 rebate to first home owners. But what is going to happen to this $7,000 rebate? It is going to be eroded over time—if Treasury and this government do not cut it out in some future budget. This $7,000, which is vital to minimising the impact, for people who do not own property, of a GST on their future housing purchases, is not set in concrete.

This is yet another example of an alleged compensation that will be eroded over time. The $7,000 is a fixed money figure. It is not indexed. There is not even an attempt to index the $7,000. If this package passes, I am sure that Treasury and Finance and this government in its approach to expenditure will cut out this $7,000—which will obviously erode over time—at some future date. That further adds to our concerns about the impact of a GST on housing.

Of course, Senator Kemp gives us the bland assurance that, okay, the $7,000 payment to first home owners is not indexed but that the states can pick it up and pay more. But we all know the pressures on state government budgets, and it is extremely unlikely that the state governments will be indexing this $7,000 payment to first home owners, and it is extremely unlikely that they would add to it. So we would get into a situation where the Commonwealth would say, `Well, you've got the GST money. You maintain the real value of the $7,000 compensation for first home owners or even increase it beyond $7,000,' and the states will say, `But we haven't got the money to do it.'

This is just another example of the government short-changing in the long term those Australians who do not own property. The GST is yet another impost barrier to that great Australian dream of home ownership, and this is but another significant example of why the Australian Labor Party opposes outright a goods and services tax and its introduction into this country.

We have just concluded a debate on food. I have made some remarks on that aspect. Food, housing, electricity prices, clothing and a whole host of other reasons—such as the lack of compensation that will last for pensioners, the increase in inflation, the failure of a GST to deliver any increase in employment in this country, and numerous other reasons—lead Labor to the conclusion that the GST should be opposed and voted down. And that is what we intend to do when we come to the conclusion of this debate.

As I have said on previous occasions—and I do not want to take the time of the Senate unduly and I do not intend to make any further remarks on this block of amendments—Labor does not believe that you can produce a soft and cuddly GST. You cannot go through and seek amendments to this package and produce a soft and cuddly GST. It is bad for the economy, it is bad for employment, and it is bad for a whole host of other reasons—and that is why it should be voted down.

talk.start.para: —Not ever amendable?
—We had that debate yesterday, Senator Margetts.

—Firstly, to respond to Senator Sherry's question previously, I am sure that the information I give may assist him in his deliberations about how to vote on this particular amendment, and so I have wanted to make sure I gave him the correct interpretation rather than something completely off the top of my head. Basically, it relates to providing for increasing the amount of rebate available when people buy, lease or get supplied, as it is defined, new residential premises on land they had already acquired as a taxable supply.

speech.para: The amount of GST they had already paid on that property will be added to the GST payable on the new residential premises. That would be added to the amount already there, for the purposes of calculating the rebates. So it means that the extra amount on the GST paid on that taxable supply—that is, the property—would be able to be added to the amount of rebate that could be claimed, by increasing the amount of GST payable for the purposes of calculating the rebate. That is four times as many words as are in the paragraph in question, but that is basically what it means.

I do want to emphasise again the importance of this area. The phrase `the necessities of life' has been thrown around a lot throughout the community in relation to tax issues in general for very many years, and housing is obviously a significant component of that. It cannot be overemphasised how crucial it is that, when we make changes of any type to the tax system—let alone one as comprehensive and fundamental as that which is being proposed here—we should clearly assess the potential impacts on such a crucial commodity as housing.

The Democrats have already indicated that, given the Senate's rejection of our amendments relating to food, we are unable to support the legislation. So we will certainly be joining with other people in voting against these bills in the final vote. But we still see it as important to do what we can—in the event that, despite the Democrats' opposition, enough other senators support the legislation that it passes—to see that other serious and significant flaws in the legislation are addressed.

Clearly, the famed warm and cuddly GST is now no longer achievable because the big, ugly spike of food tax is still in there. For that reason amongst many, the Democrats will not be able to support it. Nonetheless, if the Australian people are forced to embrace a GST, we still see it as our duty to try and remove as many as possible of the spikes that may be skewering into them when they are embracing it, against their will or otherwise. That is why we believe these, and the rest of the Democrat amendments that we will still be moving, are important, and we urge the Senate to give full consideration to them.

During the previous extended debate on the issue of food, the government made a lot of mention of the fact that a number of business organisations oppose the Democrats' approach in relation to food. Those organisations were used by the government to back its case for not exempting food. Not unreasonably, I think that in this case it would behove the government to look at what the industry groups which are involved in housing have been saying about this issue. On this issue there has been widespread criticism from business groups involved in housing about the impact of the government's tax package as it is structured at the moment and about the flaws in the First Home Owners Scheme as it is structured at the moment. The Housing Industry Association is the most prominent of those and I would suggest it has been the most vocal. To its credit, I think it has also been the most constructive in not just sitting off to one side and complaining that the government has stuffed it up but working hard and putting a lot of resources into coming up with a realistic, workable, fairer alternative which also does not impact significantly on the budget bottom line.

I think it should be congratulated for that, as should other housing organisations in the community, groups such as National Shelter and the New South Wales Federation of Housing Organisations, which have also put a lot of work into this issue. Those are community organisations rather than businesses. For whatever reason, the government often seems to think that community organisations are nice, well-meaning amateurs who really do not know what they are talking about and that we have to listen only to those engaged in making money and operating businesses. The Democrats reject that viewpoint. Indeed, we would suggest that in many cases community organisations which are involved in an issue on a non-profit basis and purely from a viewpoint of trying to achieve the best possible social outcome have a very important role to play in terms of government taking on board what these organisations see as potential impacts.

They also have an enormous amount of expertise. Indeed, the housing sector in the community—I was going to say it is well resourced, but it is certainly not well resourced—has one of the greatest degrees of expertise available amongst the non-profit community sector groupings in Australia. These organisations provide a great degree of policy initiative, and a great degree of expertise is brought to bear in analysing the impact of housing policies of various governments, or the lack of action by various governments and by industry on housing issues. The Housing Industry Association has drawn on the expertise in the community sector in ensuring proper analysis of this aspect of the taxation package.

It is not a minor matter, it is a crucial matter. I again emphasise that in this case commercial organisations, business organisations, have pointed out the flaws in the government's First Home Owners Scheme and have pointed out some of the potential negative impacts on various aspects of the housing market. Some of those are outlined in the Senate Community Affairs Committee report. It details clearly that in this case the businesses with expertise in housing issues have been quite critical of some aspects of the tax package relating to housing issues. The MBA, as well as the HIA, has brought forward significant criticisms. I think they need to be recognised, particularly in the context that Senator Sherry alluded to, which is that the amount of modelling and investigation done by the government in this area has been minimal.

I point briefly to the component of the Senate Community Affairs Committee report which spoke about the government's own estimates in this area. The report was extremely critical about that. There was a particular exchange from the committee hearings which took place in Canberra in February with officers of the department. There was questioning from members of the committee about what modelling had been done. Senator Chris Evans asked, `What about the flow-on to the cost of rents? Has the department done any work on that?' The departmental officer responded, `We have not done any modelling on the impact of the GST.' So all of this is based on Treasury modelling. Even on the flow-on to public housing there was no work done by the department responsible for housing issues and specifically for public housing. It was basically left to the public housing authorities. The departmental officer said, `The public housing authorities are doing a lot of work at the moment to identify the impacts on them.' This is work that was being done obviously many months after the tax package was put into place and was introduced into the parliament. This government was leaving it up to state housing authorities to try and figure out what the impacts were going to be on them.

Fortunately, the government have moved some way on this in relation to the amount of money they were offering under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Inasmuch as they have moved forward at all on that, certainly the Democrats are congratulating them for that. As I think was pointed out earlier, the amount of funding available under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement—firstly in terms of the amount extra that has been offered as recognition, if you like, or as compensation of the extra cost impacts of the GST—is seen by most people to be not meeting the full costs. Presumably, it is based on just another one of those Treasury underestimates. So there is an issue whether or not even a basic appropriate amount has been allocated to state public housing authorities to cope with this obvious cost impost that is going to occur.

There is also no indexation over time of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement as the offer has been put forward at the moment. Indeed, there is the wonderfully named `one per cent efficiency dividend' where funding is reduced as a reward for efficiency. So the value of the amount over time will decrease with no indexation. If the Senate refuses to support these Democrat amendments, the CPI impact will clearly be higher than it would otherwise have been. That obviously means that the lack of indexation will impact more significantly and more quickly than it otherwise would have. So there are significant negative impacts on many different aspects of the housing market. Whilst it is called a housing market, it is about providing basic shelter and accommodation for people and in some ways the fact that it is a market does not necessarily help to deliver that crucial basic social outcome.

So I and the Democrats again emphasise how crucial this issue is, partly because of the inadequacy of the government's modelling and the government's investigations into the likely impacts on all the many different components that make up housing in Australia. The Democrat amendments go straight to the heart of that issue. They provide, as I said earlier, a significant incentive for ensuring that people in private rental have their homes at an adequate standard, that standards available there do not decrease. They will certainly assist the public housing authorities, who are struggling under the inadequacies of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement as it currently stands, to address the very important role that they play.

Housing costs, I probably do not need to remind the Senate, are a fundamental component of poverty levels in Australia and, as the Democrats have pointed out both before and after the budget of this week, a tragic lack of attention is being paid to the need to tackle poverty in this country. It is all very nice to have good looking budget figures, but research continues to show it is increasing. Indeed, the Queensland Council of Social Service released a report just last week, a week before the budget, showing that poverty levels are still increasing. Housing is a significant component of that. The degree, the size, of housing costs for people on lower incomes is a significant reason why that degree of poverty is still increasing and why the gap between rich and poor is increasing. If we fail to address those issues at their source—and that is what, unfortunately, this legislation will be doing if it is not amended to address some of those flaws—we may well be contributing further to the increase in those poverty levels.

talk.start.para: —I just want to add briefly to the remarks from Senator Bartlett. With all the media and public focus on food as the core of the essentials of life argument, this housing area has indeed been missed out. This is the second most important set of amendments that the Democrats are introducing to address the area of the essentials of life, and the reason I have risen to my feet is to make very clear the different emphasis we have tried to apply in these amendments.

speech.para: The issue of the first home rebate scheme offered by the government is another one of compensation. As we have said and as other senators have said endlessly in this debate, compensation is necessary because the GST is a regressive tax. You do not give compensation—you do not give a handout—unless there is a problem. You have addressed the problem with your home buyers scheme but we feel that it is poorly targeted. The reason we feel it is poorly targeted is that, for those people on the lowest quintile of income, for those people who are poor or disadvantaged or on lower incomes, rental premises is what counts, not new homes.

If it is rental premises, it means that they are leasing from commercial providers of rented homes or from public providers of rented homes. What we have tried to do is limit the financial disincentive which presently exists in your scheme for landlords to perform needed renovations, alternations, additions or repairs to their rental properties. Under the GST, leased residential premises are input taxed and landlords will pay GST on the goods and services they acquire but they cannot claim an input tax credit for that GST. There is no GST charged on rents, which is a good policy, but still there is a financial disincentive for landlords to renovate and to improve the residential premises available for that income sector.

The reason I say it is our second most important set of amendments on the essentials of life, in trying to make the GST a far fairer tax, is that 19.3 per cent of all expenditure by lower income people is on housing and it is primarily on residential rents. So my question to the minister is: if on the one hand you have the compensation policy approach you adopted in your ANTS package, how have you addressed the other public policy—the social policy needs—of encouraging, incentivising, residential, leased premises improvements and the provision of residential leased premises? We think our amendments do just that and we are certain, from the evidence that has been provided to us, that your amendments do not. Surely you have a social obligation to encourage the provision of a better and a greater supply of more rented homes as well as the obligation to compensate for a regressive tax which hurts the poor?

talk.start.para: —I think the Democrat amendments touch on a very important point. Our position on these amendments will be as previously stated, but this is an important point—one on which the general community has again been misled by the government into thinking that there is a soft cushion here for first home buyers. Essentially, there is not. We do know that already in the real estate pages of every capital city daily real estate agents are advertising, `Buy a house before the GST inflates prices.' They are trying to encourage—and it is in their interests because they get a commission on every sale—people to buy before the GST.

speech.para: The question is: do people need to buy before the GST? Is it a credible threat that the GST will increase prices? The answer is that it is an entirely credible threat. The real estate agents are right: houses will be more expensive after a GST than before a GST. People who want to buy a house for the first time, young home buyers who are in the market to buy a house that is built and are not building their own house, will have to buy in an inflated market because the housing stock will have risen in price because of a GST. The government recognises this. There is no dispute that prices will be higher because the government has recognised this by providing, once again, what it calls `compensation'. Compensation is not available to all home buyers—it is to first home buyers. On a scale of priority, if you are awarding compensation, certainly first home buyers have a very high claim. But they are not the only people who have a claim. If a pensioner or a low income earner is in fact lining up to buy their second home, the price for their second home will be higher. There is no compensation for that class of home buyer.

talk.start.para: —The price for the first home will be higher.

—The interjection from the minister is that the price for their first home is higher, so they have pocketed the windfall gain from the first home to the second home. That assumes they are selling a home to buy a home. But a lot of people who have fallen on hard times have already sold their home and are renting. If they are trying to claw their way back up and they are going to buy again, for that group of people certainly the prices will be higher. There is no recognition of that group in the compensation package, and they will just have to find the money somewhere or go without. That explains, once again, the attitude of this government to those who really do need to have their interests considered by a parliament that expresses compassion for the lower paid and for the ordinary middle income Australians as well.

speech.para: The $7,000 first home owners rebate is, of course, uniform across Australia. What do we know about housing prices across Australia? We know that the premium market is in Sydney. The median price for a house in Sydney when I last looked was around $350,000 whereas the median price for a house in a city such as Adelaide was around $185,000. So if you are a first home buyer buying a home in Sydney you get $7,000, which is, as a percentage, of far less value to you—and not enough to offset the impact of a GST in any case—than it is to a person buying a house in Adelaide. Maybe the government's answer to that is, `Move to Adelaide.' That is also a practical impossibility for many people in this situation. That leads me to a question I have for you, Minister, and I would be grateful if you would be kind enough to provide an answer for it.

talk.start.para: —I always do.
—I notice your nod in the negative, but I took it to be affirmative. Is the $7,000 first home owners rebate means tested or not?
—The short answer to your question is yes; so I think I have covered that. If anyone else wants to speak, I will come back and answer those questions.

—I will not delay the vote on these amendments for long, but I did have a question for the minister in relation to the impact on private rentals specifically. An issue that came up a lot in the Senate Community Affairs Committee and, I am sure, in the other committees was how we stop people profiteering and unfairly increasing their prices. The ready response from the government is: `We've given extra powers to the ACCC and monstrous fines that we are going to clobber everyone on the head with when they do it.' I am interested to find out from the minister how the government sees that as operating effectively in the private rental market if you have private landlords putting up their rents by 10 per cent.

speech.para: As I have indicated, a number of community organisations have suggested that in some parts of the country some private rentals may go up by 10 per cent in any case. How will the government be able to determine if some individual landlords are profiteering by increasing rentals by 10 per cent or if they do renovations—which, if these amendments do not get up, will obviously be subject to GST and potentially increase the costs of renovations, modifications or repairs—that they are using that as a justification for extra rent hikes as well? Does the government see any prospect of adequately policing profiteering of private rentals being put up by unfair levels, particularly given the government's great aversion over many years to any form of rent control or legislated control over rent rises or rent levels? Clearly, that option is not possible. How are you actually going to catch these people when they try to rip off tenants?

I am not suggesting all landlords are evil vermin trying to suck the blood out of poor hopeless tenants or anything like that. I am talking about the occasional small number of individual landlords who may be doing the wrong thing and see it as an opportunity to whack their rents up. In certain rental markets around the country, they would be able to do that and the market would bear it. In those circumstances, how will that be adequately policed? They could quite often be private citizens who own just one or two rental properties rather than commercial operations managing tens or hundreds of properties. Do you believe that that can be adequately policed under your overall tax package?

talk.start.para: —Since we are taking the questions as a group, my first question was: is the $7,000 first home owners rebate non-means tested? When I asked that question, I heard a voice from your adviser's box say no, and then I heard you say no, Minister. I thought this was another opportunity for the advisers to get into the Hansard and create a record.
—That is very unfair.
—I do not mean it unfairly.
—Three strikes and he's out.
—I would not say that. I think he is a very good adviser and you should keep him.
—Well, stop trying to drag him into the debate.

—I am just trying to embarrass him, which I think I have done. I can now move on. This means that everyone gets the same rebate, irrespective of income. I know there is a Liberal Party philosophy of equality here. The truth is that not everyone is on the same income. If a millionaire who is buying their first home gets a rebate of $7,000 from the Australian taxpayer, I would query: is that fair? It is middle and low income earners who pay tax in this country. If a millionaire buying his or her first home is going to get a $7,000 rebate, that is a transfer of income from middle to low income earners to the wealthy. Would you agree with that, Minister? And, given that I suspect you would—because the logic is ironclad—why does the government persist in redistributing income from the poor to the rich, as it is proposing to do in this situation?

—A number of issues have been raised by Senator Murray. Senator Murray was concerned about the effect on leasing and what encouragement there would be in this package to improve leasing. Is that a fair summary of what you were saying?
—I was suggesting that our approach is better.

—I think your approach is not better. I think it is unfair, and it is certainly discriminatory against first home owners, which the government seeks to target with this particular measure. We do not think that is the case. Because it is less targeted, it benefits higher income and lower income earners but does not benefit the group which we think is the key group to compensate, given the nature of the package.

speech.para: Rental costs will probably rise by about 2.3 per cent. In a competitive housing market, we are providing very substantial compensation for individuals—we are offering the largest tax cuts in Australian history. It is obscure to us why people in the Senate wish to oppose such large tax cuts. These are the largest tax cuts ever offered, I believe, in Australian history. We have a major compensation package for people on pensions and benefits and an up-front four per cent increase and guaranteed 1.5 per cent rise above the CPI. It is a very significant and important compensation package. In relation to rental costs, the figuring we have done suggests it is about 2.3 per cent.

In relation to the monitoring of prices, Senator Bartlett indicated there is a section in the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Reform of Commonwealth-State Financial Relations which the states will be adopting to ensure that the monitoring of prices applies to the whole economy. The states and territories will be taking action to adopt the schedule version of part 5B of the Trade Practices Act 1974 and part X1AA of the new Tax System Price Exploitation Code to extend the measures in part 5B to cover those areas outside the Commonwealth's constitutional power. So the states will be enacting complementary legislation.

Senator Cook, would that we had more time to debate all this vigorously, but not at this particular moment in this chamber. Let me just assure you that we have looked closely at this. We have decided to provide $7,000 compensation for first home owners. This applies to the cost of a $150,000 house. We think it is fair and appropriate. It has been carefully researched and the government stands by its decision.

talk.start.para: —I know you think it is fair, but if a millionaire first home buyer gets $7,000 as compared with a first-time first home buyer on an ordinary salary getting $7,000, and if the tax burden is borne by middle and low income earners, that is a distribution of income from the middle to low income earners to the wealthy. I accept that that is what you think is fair, but I do not think it is fair and I think most Australians would also agree with me.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 12.30 p.m. to 1.15 p.m.

talk.start.para: —As we broke for lunch, we were discussing the somewhat skewed view the government has of fairness. Before the chamber are amendments from the Australian Democrats to change the GST package with respect to housing. The government's defence to the allegation of unfairness in its treatment of home buyers is that it has provided a $7,000 first home owners rebate. My question to the minister was: is that rebate means tested? His answer is: no, it's not. The only conclusion is, therefore, that since middle and low income earners pay most of the taxation collected by the government in Australia, and there is no rebate or means test on the First Home Owners Scheme, then a wealthy person—a millionaire—can claim the $7,000 rebate just as a middle or low income earner can, and because of where tax is collected from—which class of income it is collected from—that is a redistribution of wealth from middle and low income earners to wealthy people.

speech.para: The government says that is fair, and I accept that is the Liberal Party definition of fairness. But there is a budget allocation for the amount of money for first home owners to presumably meet this $7,000 grant. Wouldn't it be fairer, Minister, given the higher prices that are occurring now in the real estate market, to draw the line somewhere and say, `People above a certain income level will not attract the rebate,' and provide a better and bigger rebate for people below that level? Wouldn't that be fairer? Why should, for example, Jamie Packer, if he was buying his first home, get $7,000 from middle and low income earners, and a middle and low income earner get the same amount?

talk.start.para: —I do not think you understand. It is capped at $7,000 and, therefore, a person who buys a lower value house gets the higher proportional benefit from this scheme. We have capped it at $7,000. We think this is a fair system; we think it is a carefully targeted system, and it deals with an issue that came up in order to make sure that first home buyers were not adversely affected. It is a capped scheme—that is a well-known way of dealing with these things. Lower income people will presumably not be able to buy as expensive a house as higher income people; therefore, it provides the greatest proportionate benefit to that category.

—That is one way, but you would agree with me that another way which would be doubly beneficial would be to also means test it. However, let me move on. If you regard that arrangement as fair, why do you regard it as fair that, in calculating the inflationary impact of the introduction of a 10 per cent GST on just about everything, you exclude housing costs? The figure of 1.9 per cent that you tell us is the inflationary impact of a 10 per cent GST is, as we now know, not true—that is, the inflationary impact calculated by the Department of Treasury for the second year of the GST. In the first year, the Treasury's calculation of inflationary impact is 3.1 per cent based on a set of assumptions that are challengeable, and the realistic inflationary impact is probably more like four to five per cent. But in calculating your figure of the inflationary impact, you exclude housing; and we now know—and you have confessed it, or confirmed it—that housing prices will be higher under a GST. Why are you excluding from inflationary impacts the question of housing?

—Senator, let me make it clear. The government wants a fair scheme; it wants a simple scheme. The government is very aware of the incentive effects that come with withdrawal rates and means testing. What we are doing is providing a capped scheme which is well understood. It provides a higher proportionate benefit to people who purchase a lower value house than, say, to wealthy people who might purchase a higher value house. We have had long debates on the inflation figures, both in the committee and elsewhere, and we have excluded housing costs, as you know, because we have a First Home Owners Scheme which provides compensation to first home owners.

—Just to tie this point down—it is probably my last question; and I am happy, subject to any further debate in the chamber, to go to a vote on this proposition: firstly, you acknowledge housing prices will be higher because of a GST—that is a matter that is now established—and you compensate for first home owners by a scheme or a grant which in some cities may meet their needs but in other cities will not because of the varying prices of entry into home ownership. In Sydney it is much more pricey to buy a house than it is in Adelaide, Perth or even here in Canberra. One size fits all—so they all get the same rebate. You will not put a means test on that so that the wealthy get the same as middle and low income earners, and you think that is fair because of the cap. But you exclude the price of housing from your inflationary calculations as to what the real price of the introduction of a GST will be. Can I be absolutely sure about this: your reason for not calculating into inflation the higher prices of housing because of a GST is simply because you have got this scheme? Is that the only explanation you can provide?

—I note that this is your last question, and I hope that this is the case. I noticed that Senator Sherry said that he was not going to make a further contribution, and I rather unwisely assumed that was the end of the Labor Party contribution. I will not make that mistake again.

speech.para: (1) Clause 38-10, page 79 (after line 9), after table item 4, insert:
4A Complementary medicine
(8) Clause 195-1, page 271 (line 19), at the end of the definition of recognised professional , add:
; or (d) in the case of services covered by item 4A in the table—the service is supplied by a person who is accredited as a member of a body listed in Schedule 1 of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations.

These two amendments relate to complementary medicine. Until this committee inquiry got under way and I started getting submissions on health issues, I had previously used the term `alternative medicine'. If I lapse into that term, please replace those words with `complementary medicine'.

These amendments make complementary medicines GST free where they are provided by a practitioner who is a member of a recognised professional association. The legislation presented by the government lists a range of health services that are GST free. It lists particular services in a table, including chiropody, dental, dietary, nursing, occupational therapy, osteopathy, pharmacy, psychology, social work, speech therapy, speech pathology, podiatry and a few others. The first amendment simply seeks to insert complementary medicine amongst those other services. The second amendment includes an enhanced definition of `recognised professional' for those people in complementary medicine services where the services are provided by a person who is accredited as a member of a body listed in schedule 1 of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations.

Natural and complementary medicine is an important part of Australia's health care system. It is not some obscure fringe activity. It is widely used by many Australians. More and more Australians are using a range of so-called non-mainstream medicines such as herbal medicine, acupuncture and naturopathy and are benefiting from using these types of health care. I am sure that all of us have had personal testimony from members of the public about the benefits they have found from using this type of health care and how it suits their needs. When we are making major changes to our taxation system—legislation does not get any more major than this—it is important to reflect the changing face of health care in Australia and people's increasingly diverse choices of health care. It is important to ensure that we do not do anything to negate the availability or affordability of those choices.

Complementary medicine helps people to remain healthy and avoid further illnesses. It has a strong preventative focus, which is something that mainstream medicine is sometimes criticised for not having. Any type of medicine that prevents future illness, as complementary medicine clearly does, saves costs elsewhere in the health budget. The Democrats support Australians in choosing complementary medicine and recognise that consumers of complementary medicine do not already receive government subsidies for these services. We do not believe that these consumers should face a further financial burden because they choose a mode of health care that is outside the mainstream medical model.

Imposing a GST on complementary medicine would be discriminatory and contrary to competition policy. It would assist one section of the market over another. It would discriminate in favour of doctors who can perform or prescribe complementary medicine and then claim Medicare benefits as with ordinary consultations. This discrimination results in anomalies. Complementary medicine services such as acupuncture are GST free when provided by a hospital or a doctor but incur a GST when supplied by a trained acupuncturist who is likely to be highly trained, more experienced and more skilled in this area. That is not a reflection on GPs who practise acupuncture; it is simply a statement of fact. Trained acupuncturists who practise solely in that field tend to have more training than GPs in that specific discipline.

Evidence provided to the Senate Community Affairs Committee, which I was the Democrats member on, was that people may decide to go to bulk-billing doctors instead of natural therapists in order to receive a GST-free and heavily subsidised service. This would represent an increase in the costs of Medicare and would not result in an optimum use of health resources. It is important to note that some types of complementary medicine, such as acupuncture, are more commonly used than many of the health services specified by the government as being GST free—and I read through some of those earlier. Acupuncture, to focus on that one specifically, has been widely accepted as a mainstream health service. Rebates are paid by all but one national health insurer for acupuncture services. A number of health insurers also rebate for other complementary medicine services, such as Chinese herbal medicine. Many rebate for the specific skilled provision of massage therapy as well.

The amendments that the Democrats are moving today would bring this legislation into line with what is already occurring in the community. We are trying to create a tax system for the next century. To put it mildly, we think it is short-sighted to not have this brand new, whizzbang, new millennium tax system up to speed with where the community already is now, let alone where it will be next century. This approach has already been picked up by the private health insurance industry. I think the Democrats' amendments are a positive move for complementary medicine and for the wider community, who will benefit from an increased choice of affordable health care options. It is another example of an attempt by the Democrats and by community organisations to genuinely participate in constructively assessing the tax proposals put forward by the government in an important area of health care.

The government went to the election saying that health services would be GST free. They did not define that at the time. They had the very brief Vos inquiry to examine where to draw the line there. Senator Kemp will be relieved to know that I will not revisit the food debate, but it is another example of people saying that somehow, if we made food GST free, everything would collapse but, if we can make some health services GST free, the government think that is all right. They have had to decide where to draw the line, in the same way as you would have to decide where to draw the line if you were exempting food. Those sorts of things are not necessarily simple, but they are certainly achievable. The government have chosen to draw a line here which, in our view, leaves a very narrow definition—or perhaps an insufficiently broad definition—of health services because it leaves out a whole range of complementary medicine services.

As I said at the start of my contribution, these services are widely used by many Australians. I should probably say, by way of declaring an interest in this, that I am not one of those Australians who use complementary medicine services. No doubt due to my conservative nature, I stick to traditional mainstream medicine. But I know many Australians who do use these services, and I know a growing number of people use them. I do recognise that they are important, not just because they provide and meet the health needs of many people much better than mainstream health services but also because they have a very strong preventive focus. I think that is something that should be encouraged wherever possible in health practice. It is very counterproductive to put an in-built disincentive into our taxation system.

In putting forward and promoting these amendments, I also remind the Senate that it is another example of putting forward con structive suggestions based partly on information provided from the community. People in the community who have experience in these areas have tried to constructively engage and put forward constructive solutions. It is also a cost-effective solution. In our view, it would save the government money, particularly in the long term, by not providing extra incentives for people to go into the subsidised health system that currently exists and by enabling a continued expansion in accordance with the direct choices of the Australian people in their health needs. So these amendments have a lot going for them. I do wish that the government and the rest of the Senate would take them seriously. Regardless of a lot of the other debates surrounding the tax package, it is these sorts of crucial issues that we believe need to be addressed and fixed up.

As I have already said previously today, the Democrats will not be supporting the overall legislation because of the unfairness that is now entrenched in it by the rejection of some of our previous amendments. I would also suggest that these are just the sorts of issues that are unlikely to be picked up in any agreement that may be reached between the government and other senators. They are more likely to be looking at the big picture items. These sorts of issues that are smaller and more discrete are unlikely to be picked up, although I certainly hope they are. I think it is essential for the Senate, in its role as a house of parliament considering proposed legislation, to consider amending these issues. I would hope that the ALP would look at them in that light as well.

talk.start.para: —These amendments extend the current medical exemption to include complementary medicine on the register of therapeutic goods. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Senator Tambling, is actually working in quite a constructive way in this area to find better ways of dealing with the issue and working with the industry, which is of course large and still growing. To be listed on this register, the goods must have been shown to be of acceptable safety, quality and efficacy. speech.para: Why is this necessary? Complementary medicine providers are discriminated against. Mainstream doctors who practise some complementary techniques will have their services classified as GST free. This is a clear issue of equity in the same service. It also exacerbates the current discrimination that applies to mainstream doctors, who can supply complementary services and receive a Medicare rebate for doing so. Complementary health practitioners, though, do not have access to this concession for their patients. It is an issue of choice for consumers. The government has acknowledged that many people actually prefer complementary techniques and medicines in their health care regime. I think it does mean that people feel that they sometimes have a little more control in the way they choose their health care.

Consistent with the government initiatives in this area—and I mentioned those of Senator Tambling; for instance, the establishment of an Office of Complementary Medicine and enhancement of a Complementary Medicines Evaluation Committee—you would think that the government would think carefully about making sure that these positive efforts are linked in their package in what is considered to be `health care'. As Senator Bartlett has indicated, complementary medicines and, indeed, preventative and community health care often mean that you have a lot fewer people end up at the pointy end, the critical end, of medical services. And that, in effect, is a very cost-effective way of keeping the community as healthy as possible. Therefore, obviously, the Greens (WA) will be supporting these amendments.
