talk.start.para: —I seek to return to Greens (WA) amendment No. 1 on sheet 1392. I move:

speech.para: Clause 38-10, page 79 (after table item 1), insert:
1A Acupuncture

As I mentioned before, this is related to the amendments which have just been defeated, but it is different. It is actually more specific. Honourable senators will remember that Senator Bartlett mentioned acupuncture amongst his list of complementary medicines he was hoping to encapsulate. This amendment adds acupuncture to the list of the 18 other health services specified in the legislation as being GST free. Thus, acupuncture will attract the same exemptions as health services such as chiropractic, occupational therapy, speech therapy and dietary services.

Why do this? Firstly, acupuncture already meets the criteria for GST-free status. It is argued that acupuncture already meets the requirement for inclusion in table 38.10. The Vos committee noted that the health services included in 38.10 would generally be considered by the community to be mainstream rather than complementary or alternative, and they have been available as specialist services with specific qualifications for some time. That is from page 28 of the Vos report.

Acupuncture is, of course, commonly used and widely accepted and can be considered a mainstream health service. Private health insurance administration council statistics reveal that acupuncture is a more frequently used health service than many others on the GST-free list, including speech therapy, dietary services and occupational therapy. Certainly acupuncture and traditional Chinese medicine are mainstream therapies in some of Australia's major Asian trading partners, including China, Japan, Singapore and Taiwan.

The fact that Victoria is currently drafting legislation for the registration of acupuncturists is additional evidence to show its general acceptance. In addition, a large number of private health insurers already provide rebates for acupuncture services provided by qualified practitioners. The accreditation standards set by the Australian Acupuncture and Chinese Medicine Association have been the benchmark for providing recognition by all the major insurers, and about 80 per cent of practitioners belong to this peak professional body.

Anticompetitive and discriminatory arrangements exist between acupuncture and traditional Chinese medicine services as provided by qualified professionals, and those provided by GST-free medical practitioners. Acupuncture is a recognised Medicare service when performed by a doctor but is not when provided by professional acupuncturists. Often medical practitioners may have completed only short courses in acupuncture, whereas a qualified acupuncturist will have undertaken a three- to four-year accredited degree or higher degree program.

There are some 1,200 to 1,300 qualified acupuncture professionals presently practising who meet these requirements, as well as 1,200 general medical practitioners who regularly use acupuncture. The Australian Acupuncture and Chinese Medicine Association Ltd is the peak body regulating most qualified acupuncturists. The organisation accredits acupuncture practitioners, sets standards of ethics and practice, deals with complaints from the public, and disciplines practitioners who breach the rules and ethics.

If this legislation goes through unamended in this area it will increase the financial disincentive for a person to go to a fully qualified acupuncturist. Not only do you not get a Medicare rebate, but also now the service will cost an extra 10 per cent. The inclusion of acupuncture does not require the government to extend the categories of goods or services which are to be exempted, nor does it require the government to change or add to the definition of a recognised professional. The government has apparently told the acupuncturists that cost is an issue. However, this seems to be an unfair argument considering that the costs do not seem to a factor when giving GST-free status to the other health services or, indeed, as Senator Cook would be quick to add, to high-rollers.

It is also necessary to consider the fact that the cost savings from Medicare are likely to fall if acupuncture is given GST-free status. When provided by a GP, with possibly less than one month's training, it costs the government $18.45 and the quality of health care may be questionable, whereas if a patient visits an acupuncturist it costs the government nothing.

Medical practitioners provide around 900,000 acupuncture services per year, costing around $17 million to Medicare. It might be that there is $3 million in lost revenue from GST if acupuncture were deemed GST free.
I would like to read from a response that has been sent to us from the Australian Acupuncture and Chinese Medicine Association, which says:
The acupuncturists and practitioners of traditional Chinese medicine, in addition to the . . . arguments—
in relation to the cost for their inclusion in the GST list—

of choice and savings to the health system, also argued that they currently met the criteria used by the Government in determining the GST free list. Their services are commonly used and wide accepted, mainstream . . . services. Private Health Insurance Administration Council statistics reveal that acupuncture is a more frequently used health service than many on the GST free list.
Acupuncture is a recognised Medicare service when provided by a doctor, but it is not when provided by a professional acupuncturist.

And we have seen the evidence from Victoria. The reason for moving this amendment is to indicate that there is something we can do which is sensible and does not stretch the principles or lack of principles which the government has set for this debate. It does not require any major changes to the legislation except to suggest that we put something in which is sensible, commonly used and is considered by many people to be make important contribution. (Quorum formed)

Here we have something which meets the criteria set by the Vos committee. It meets the needs of many people—a growing number of people. It is considered mainstream in a number of neighbouring countries and by many people in the Australian community as well. Under any guise of some definitions of complementary medicine, there is no reason not to include this as a GST-free treatment. It defies reason not to do so.

This is a very reasonable amendment. If this chamber does not pass this amendment, we are going to have to come back at some time down the line and introduce some form of legislation to include acupuncture. It is on the verge of being included anyway. In this instance, we can see just how silly the government is in relation to digging in its heels on things which concern the community. I suppose in some ways this is a challenge to the opposition—and we have seen what has happened in respect of a number of these amendments.

I urge support for this amendment because, quite frankly, it is just crazy to single out acupuncture and say that treatment by unqualified or semiqualified acupuncturists, provided they have a degree in medicine, will get a GST rebate but that treatment by qualified fully trained acupuncturists will not.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats support the amendment moved by Senator Margetts. It is eminently sensible, for the reasons she has just outlined as well as for reasons I outlined in relation to the previous Democrat amendment. The amendment specifically inserts acupuncture as a health service among 18 other specified GST-free health services, some of which I read out previously, which are detailed in the legislation. This is another example of the way the parliamentary process and the committee process should work in considering government proposals adequately, not only to ensure that they are fair, equitable and do good things, but to ensure that they do what the government says they are going to do and meet the government's own criteria.

speech.para: The government went before the electorate and said that health would be GST free. We have already pointed out that a number of health services are not GST free. An attempt was made to raise this issue in the very brief and inadequate time frame prior to Christmas when the Vos inquiry was being discussed. As Senator Margetts has just pointed out, acupuncture clearly fits within the principles contained in the rationale for the detailing of services that are GST free. Bearing in mind all the arguments that have been made about complementary medicine—and I do not know whether the minister can come up with any justification; there certainly was not any in the committee hearings—this service should blatantly, obviously, justifiably and clearly sit in the group of GST-free health services.

It is far more widely used than many of those that are GST free. It is clearly professionally recognised. It qualifies for rebates with private health insurers. It is a major complementary medicine service. It has a long-established history of use, both in Australia and overseas. Obviously, it has been far longer established overseas. (Quorum formed)

I recognise that the arguments I am putting are so compelling that it needed to have extra people to come in and listen to them. Hopefully, they can convince their government colleagues to support Senator Margetts's amendment in this stage. Indeed, Senator Kemp assures me he is listening closely to the argu ments, so I will try and put them forward as compellingly as possible. In some ways, it does not need a compelling argument to be put, because it is such an obvious matter that needs to be addressed.

The one and only question I would ask the minister on this amendment is for him to give us one possible logical reason why acupuncture should not be amongst the list of exempt health services. What is the reason that acupuncture does not fit the criteria? What is the principle that acupuncture fails to meet that all these other services do meet? That is the one question I would put to the government.

Again, the plea I would make to the ALP in relation to these amendments is that the Democrats have said throughout the day that we will not be supporting this bill when it comes to a vote at the end of the proceedings but that we still believe it is our duty and our responsibility to improve it in whatever way we can, in case it is accepted by the government and by sufficient other senators at the end of the day and the Australian public get the legislation anyway.

Whatever it is that the government may be discussing with other senators in this chamber about the GST legislation, they have not been negotiating with the Democrats for quite some time. Possibly they are discussing things with other senators at the moment. I do not know precisely what is being proposed, but I can be quite sure that, whatever the government is discussing at the moment with other senators, it does not include acupuncture. I suspect that it is probably not at the top of the agenda and probably nowhere in the middle or at the bottom of the agenda. I fear it will slip off the agenda entirely.

Unless we in the Senate do what we can to make these changes to the legislation here on the floor of the chamber, I suspect that any other agreements that are reached outside this chamber will not include measures such as these, because they are not big enough ticket items; but they clearly will affect a lot of people. It is clearly counterproductive and it is clearly unfair.

I would again urge the ALP to consider supporting even just this small amendment. I am quite sure that, if it did go through, it would not be the straw that broke the camel's back and led the government to throw the whole package out as unsustainable because acupuncture was GST free. It will not compromise the integrity of the whole tax system. It will not destroy it in the way that arguments have been made about other amendments. It is a simple one; it is a technical one; it is justifiable. I urge all senators to support it.

talk.start.para: —I do not have anything to say at all on this amendment, having put our position down previously with respect to the amendments en bloc from the Greens and from the Australian Democrats. I agree, though, with the intent of the amendment. Of course the GST should not apply in this case. However, as you would expect me to say, it should not apply in any case, not just in this one. As a consequence, we will not be supporting the amendment.
—I have listened carefully to the arguments, as I promised to Senator Margetts and Senator Bartlett. I have to say that I am unpersuaded.
—Tell us what the hole is in our acupuncture argument.

—In its consideration of the GST-free treatment of the health sector, the government's main concern is to have as broadly based a tax as possible while recognising the need to ensure a level playing field for both private and public suppliers of health goods and services. The current list does not include services that most people would regard as complementary medicine. I think that point was sensibly canvassed in the Democrat amendment that we had before—and as I said, I listened carefully to it.

speech.para: The government has listed as GST free health services that would generally be considered by the community as mainstream rather than as complementary or—to use the term used by Senator Bartlett—alternative. The government recognises that there are many services, including recreational pursuits, that may have health benefits. But, at the end of the day the government does have to draw the line at a reasonable point. As you would be aware, a great deal of work and thought has gone into the drawing of the line. The Vos committee was very useful in helping to set the boundaries. The government believes the way the line has been drawn is appropriate. Therefore, after due consideration, we will not be supporting the amendments which Senator Margetts has moved.

talk.start.para: —I actually thought that Senator George Campbell was going to make a contribution to the acupuncture debate, but I was obviously mistaken. Senator Campbell indicates that he has had acupuncture, as have I. I must declare an interest, in that I have benefited from acupuncture myself. I would like to thank Senator Kemp for bringing up the Vos argument again. It was the very argument that we were making: under the definitions and the criteria of the Vos committee—and the Vos committee was not perfect—acupuncture would actually fit. So thank you for reinforcing our argument. You still have not punctured our acupuncture argument, I am afraid. Therefore, because it is such a nit-picking approach that the government are taking—they will listen to business but will not listen to members of the community and will not listen to general health and equity issues—we are going to have to call for a division on this just to show how silly the positions are in relation to this.

speech.para: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: (25) Clause 38-25, page 81 (lines 7 to 11), omit subclause (1), substitute:
(1) A supply of services is GST-free if:
(a) it is a supply of services covered by Schedule 1 to the *Quality of Care Principles; and
(b) it is provided through a residential care service (within the meaning of the Aged Care Act 1997 ); and
(c) the supplier is an approved provider (within the meaning of that Act).
(26) Clause 38-25, page 81 (line 26), after "include", insert ", and are only provided to people who require,".
(27) Clause 38-25, page 81 (after line 29), at the end of the clause, add:
(4) A supply of accommodation is GST-free if it is made to a person in the course of making a supply to that person that is GST-free under subsection (1), (2) or (3).

(5) However, a supply of services that is covered by an extra services fee within the meaning of Division 35 of the Aged Care Act 1997 is only GST-free under this section to the extent that the services are covered by Schedule 1 to the *Quality of Care Principles.

These three amendments, on sheet FA210, clarify the scope of the government's proposals to make residential care GST free. Request 25 seeks to ensure that all services covered by schedule 1 of the quality of care principles delivered by facilities that are approved providers under the Aged Care Act 1997 will be GST free whether or not a subsidy is payable to the recipient of the service. Request 26 seeks to ensure that the services provided in privately funded residential care facilities are GST free only for residents requiring nursing services or daily living activities assistance. Request 27 will ensure that accommodation services provided at approved residential premises are GST free and that paying extra to receive extra services is GST free only if the services are covered by schedule 1 of the quality of care principles.

talk.start.para: —These are government amendments to its own legislation which give effect to a government undertaking. The principle is a reasonable principle if you support a GST. When we commenced the committee stage of this debate, the government had announced 128 amendments to its own legislation. Since then it has announced further amendments. By our count, there are now 143 amendments that the government has proposed to its own legislation. I note again that this is legislation the government put to the House of Representatives in December of last year which it claimed was perfect and which it demanded that the House attend to immediately. It denied the House proper opportunity to debate the legislation and introduced a guillotine to force the legislation through by Christmas.

speech.para: Now that we come to the Senate, there are now 143 amendments the government proposes to its own legislation. I wish the government would get its housekeeping right and be able to at least draft the legislation that it expects to put through the parliament. I wish it would treat the House of Representatives as a proper debating chamber and not simply as a rubber stamp for executive government. Having said that, at least this is a proper debating chamber, for the reason that the government does not have a majority here. If it did, clearly we too would be treated as a rubber stamp. Fortunately, the government does not have a majority, so we can examine these matters and debate them. I want to record those views for the record. To the principle of the amendments I have no objection.

talk.start.para: —I just want to address a process remark to the minister. There has been a claim made that all parties arrived at this debate with their positions firmly tied and nothing was changed as a result of the Senate select committee and references committee process. But we have just been through a series of amendments—on housing, and on health in relation to alternative medicine and other things—which specifically emerged as a result of evidence to the committees. The government has seen fit to turn down Democrat and Greens amendments which arose from submissions and from evidence to those committees which indicated in what respects the bills were deficient. Here is the government doing the very same thing. The government drew up those bills. I do not know where we are now, Senator Cook, with the number of ANTS bills, but I am sure it is about 35, from what I have seen coming through the House of Representatives.
—Yes.

—Quite frankly, it is impossible for the very finest draftsperson and the very best government to get every word, clause, phrase and prospect right when you are designing 35 bills with such a wide range of reform.

speech.para: The point that Senator Cook is making is that the government went out and said how perfect this package was and that it could not be and should not be changed in any respect—and we always thought that was an absolutely ludicrous approach to take. We think the government is perfectly right and perfectly proper in actually finding mistakes and fixing them, and the amendments before us fall into that category. It is a wise and a sensible response to deficient drafting.

Why should we on this side of the House take that rational, responsible and reasonable response to government considerations which are as a result of better reflection. Because do not forget: the government put this through in 20 hours in the House of Representatives. They forced it through and if they had had their way this would already be law and these amendments would never have appeared from the government side. That is what they wanted the Senate to do, and yet with up to 143 meaningful amendments from the government to address that problem.

Quite frankly, what I find galling, from the point of view of the crossbenches, is that amendments put up which reflect considerations arising from the Senate committee process—which are constructive consequences to an understanding of problems, weaknesses and deficiencies in the legislation—are treated by a stonewalling government in the way they are and yet we on our side are taking a responsible, reflective and constructive response to the government amendments. If we wanted to get nasty with this stuff, we could take the view that we just oppose it all, and yet we do not do that.

I just want to again make the point, Minister, which I made right at the very beginning of the debate: if you go through this entire package of bills with 143 amendments on your side and probably 130 or 140 amendments—I have not counted them—from the crossbenches and you do not accept one of those amendments, just look out, because we will have a long memory for unreasonableness. That is a clear warning to you, because I do not think it is humanly possible for every single one of our amendments to be unacceptable to the government. Of course I understand the food one; you have a profound difference in policy. Of course I understand many of the others, but a lot of our amendments too and those of the Greens (WA) are also technical and improve matters. That is probably a bad tempered response at the end of a long week, but I do want to contrast the way in which we deal with your amendments and the way in which you deal with ours.

talk.start.para: —I do have a question of the minister in relation to these amendments, and perhaps also procedurally the Democrats have an amendment to government amendment 27. I know the government amendments were moved by leave together; I do not know if that generates a problem or not. If not, I would seek to move the Democrat amendment to the amendment. We have an amendment to omit a subclause in government amendment 27.
—You are in order, Senator.
—I move Democrats' amendment on sheet 1389:

speech.para: Omit subclause 38-25(5)

Dealing with these amendments separately, although later I might speak to the lot at once, the Democrats support government amendment 25. It removes the current requirements that a residential aged care subsidy must be payable for the service to be GST free. It would have meant that some residents of nursing homes would have had to pay a GST on accommodation services and would also have meant that residents who receive no subsidy for their accommodation costs, due to the means test, would have had to pay a GST on their nursing home fees. This is a positive amendment and, therefore, the Democrats are willing to be constructive and support it. As Senator Murray said, we wish the government would take a similar approach to our constructive amendments. We do not believe that older Australians should have to pay a GST on nursing home and residential accommodation fees, and we are pleased to see an amendment from the government that addresses some of those concerns.

Government amendment 26, which again relates to GST-free residential care, deals with a clarification specifying the services to be provided to people who require the services set out in item 2.1 at part 2 of the schedule and in item 3.8 in part 3 of that schedule, which in plain English means nursing services or daily living activity services. It appears to me to narrow the definition slightly. The Democrats believe that people who require supported accommodation should not have to pay a GST for the services they require, and they should not have to pay for services they require as part of their supported accommodation needs. Many residents of nursing homes do not require nursing services but they do require some level of supported accommodation services. I want to clarify that with the government because it appears, on my reading of this amendment, that it would actually narrow the scope somewhat and require some people to pay a GST on their supported accommodation needs.

In relation to government amendment 27 and the Democrat amendment we have moved to that, government amendment 27 contains two subclauses. Subclause (4), which we support, clarifies the application of the GST on residential aged care accommodation. Subclause (5) states that services under this section are GST free only to the extent the services are covered by schedule 1 to the quality of care principles and that any additional services would incur a GST.

So we support subclause (4) which ensures the supply of accommodation is GST free but we oppose subclause (5) which, in our view, would restrict the GST-free status to those services covered under the quality of care principles and would result in some older Australians who already pay an extra service fee for the services they require having to pay an additional tax to continue to receive those services. That appears to the Democrats to be inequitable. I would appreciate a response from the minister on that question. It is an important amendment that the Democrats have moved—sufficiently important, I note, for the press gallery to be suddenly filled with people, so it must be an important matter. I hope that, with the enhanced audience, Minister, you might be able to address the couple of questions I have raised in relation to your amendments.

talk.start.para: —If I may speak to the amendments in a broad way, if the committee does not mind me doing that, and refer to the whole of the proposed new tax system—of course, in referring to that, one of necessity has a view about these particular amendments—we all agree that this new tax system proposed by the government is a major revolutionary reform and that, good or bad, we will have to live with it for decades to come. A huge effort has been expended by the government and by others in developing this new tax system proposal. The effort that has gone into it includes the physical, professional and mental costs for people, both from within the government and from outside.

speech.para: The executive government has put forward this proposal pursuant to what it considers to be a mandate given by the people at the October election. Much has been said about this question of mandate, and I am not going to enter into that argument at this point in time other than to say that the question of mandate, in my experience in the 24 years I have been here, has been brought into focus by some governments on the basis that the latest election has been for the House of Representatives, and that is the case when there are half-Senate elections. I do not know whether it is an appropriate call on the mandate when you have senators who have been elected but who are not yet in this chamber, but that is an aside. There have been other suggestions that people considered themselves to be informed but in fact were not fully informed, and I do not blame the government for that; it gave its best effort there. Furthermore, if you have a look at the votes in the last election, it may well be argued that the people did not fully support this measure.

The Senate has its role, and that has been expressed readily over the years. The founders of the Constitution realised what they were doing by giving each house of parliament its proper functions. One of our functions in this bicameral system is one of review. We are the house of review and regularly exercise that review. This is being done here in this committee stage and was done during the second reading stage and by the Senate committees that investigated this matter over a considerable period of time. I had the honour to be part of the Senate Select Committee on a New Tax System as a participating member. That committee worked from December last year until it gave its report last month.

Millions and millions of words have been spoken and written about this package. I am not going to repeat them because all of that has been said and done. There have been arguments for and against this package. Reasons have been advanced by the government for the necessity of this package, including one that the current revenue raising system is broke. There have been other suggestions by people on the other side of the fence who say, `If the revenue raising system is broke, what of the current and continuing budget surpluses?'

There have been questions as to whether or not the package will deliver for export industries. Again, there have been other ways suggested as to how that could be achieved. There is the question of whether employment will be generated by this package—one very important matter for me, and of course for all of us. When one looks at the package one sees that there are winners and losers. One of the big losers is tourism and one of the winners is the manufacturing industry. There are plenty of the former in my home state of Tasmania and not much of the latter.

Nevertheless, one needs to look at these matters on an overall basis, in the interests of the nation as a whole. I will not go into the principles I proposed in my second reading contribution, but I did mention one thing that I want to mention again here, and that is that the family is the fundamental group unit of our society and whatever is done should be family friendly. Unfortunately, the GST proposal regards the costs of raising children to be discretionary consumption. I believe it is very important that investment in children should be recognised as a social and economic necessity for the future wellbeing of this nation.

The government has proposed to all and sundry that that is what it is doing with its family tax cuts. You can do that without a GST. That is evident by the government's ANTS package document whereby the government is proposing to pay for these tax cuts by running down the deficit, principally and with the business tax. That almost equals the amount of money that is needed for the tax cuts in the third year. So in essence it could be—and has been—argued on the other side that many of the tax cuts are required to pay back to taxpayers what they have already paid in bracket creep and the like.

I have been told to keep in there and try to develop compensation for a better result. I have been asked to do that by some very close friends—not my wife, I might say. Sorry, she is a close friend—in fact she is my closest friend—and she and other friends have been urging me to be very careful before voting on this particular aspect of the tax package. With due respect to all of them, I have attempted to do that. I have followed this, and I have been backwards and forwards through all the technical details of the proposal. I am very grateful to those within the professions and within business who have given me technical and professional advice.

The government has looked at the adequacy of compensation again and, to be fair to the government, it has sought to examine how best those compensation packages could be improved. For example, within the last day or so, there have been further suggestions by the government in respect of improving the family tax element of the package, better compensation for social security recipients, pensioners and the like, as well as for those who have no relationship with the government either through the taxation or social security systems. I thank the government for the work it has done on that and on a number of other areas as well. I believe the government may well reveal those. I do not feel that I am in a position to do so at this particular juncture. They were quite significant improvements to the package, to my way of thinking.

Again, I will not go over what I said during the second reading debate. I enunciated the taxation principles that I believe should apply and against which the tax package should be tested—not only the classic ones of efficiency, equity and simplicity but the other matters that I raised in the second reading debate. I did say that taxation, as we all know, has a social as well as an economic dimension. The question that I have to answer is whether a significant part of the package meets the fundamental principles that I outlined. One of the fundamental principles is the capacity to pay. I think people all around this chamber will agree that the GST is inherently regressive. We all agree with that. The question is whether compensation is adequate. That is the question in my mind that is raised for the government.

The question now in my mind is whether it is inherently regressive to such an extent that it should not be supported. The GST burdens the poor and those with the least capacity to pay. It discriminates against the poor and the pensioners who are living a hand-to-mouth existence and spending the bulk of their income on the necessities of life—food, clothing, rent, heating, power, bus fares and so on. Hard-pressed parents who are spending money on their families and raising children—the future taxpayers—are forced by this very tax into a means tested compensation package from the outlays side of the budget.

We all know that when that is done, people look at the outlays later on, down the track—and I have been here for 24 years, and I have seen it before—and they say, `They do not need welfare.' They should not have to rely on welfare where that is avoidable, but in this case they are forced into it. And, as we know, those who are advantaged by this package are those who are the savers. Persons who cannot save are really faced with a 10 per cent increase in their income tax. There is no need for me to go into that. People realise that that is the situation. The pattern of expenditure for disabled people and for those who are chronically ill and elderly is more burdensome than for those without such disabilities. I have always been conscious of the fact that the true test of a civilised society is how it regards and treats its most vulnerable.

But I do not claim here a monopoly on moral judgments in respect of this. I do not criticise the government, and I do not reflect upon the government or on any of its members. I just happen to believe that the inherently regressive nature of the GST does not achieve that test. The regressive nature of the goods and services tax is why compensation is invariably needed to secure its passage wherever it is introduced throughout the world. The government's genuine attempt to compensate and to lock in that compensation is something to be commended, but it cannot be guaranteed.

But one thing can be guaranteed, and that is that the goods and services tax, once enshrined in legislation, will never be removed. Decisions we make now on this issue are not for the next three years; we are making decisions here that will affect generations. The question that I have to ask myself is whether I am going to be a party to imposing an impersonal, indiscriminate tax on my children, my grandchildren and their children for generations to come. I cannot.

This has been a bitter decision for me to come to, because I respect the government and I respect the Prime Minister of Australia. One of the most difficult things that I had to do—and I wanted to face him man-to-man, but he is engaged on the work of government up in Brisbane—was to speak to him over the phone not so long ago, about an hour ago. I can only apologise to those in the government who have spent so much time—Minister Kemp, Senator Brian Gibson, Senator Alan Ferguson and all of those other people. I apologise, but I have to live with my own decisions. I know my name will be mud, whichever way it goes, but it has been mud before today, and it will be mud again later on.

I do apologise, but I did my best to see whether or not in the end I could support the measure. I must say that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer knew my predisposition, because I made it perfectly clear. One of the major reasons that I kept on trying to find ways through in my own mind and in my own examination of the package was that I had been urged to do so by people whom I know and respect. Then again, I was urged not to do so by other people whom I know and respect. Madam Temporary Chair Crowley, I thank you and the committee for your courtesy in allowing me to make this statement.

talk.start.para: —Naturally, it will not surprise the chamber if I indicate that the government is disappointed with the decision that Senator Harradine has made at this stage. We believe that the package of reforms to Australia's tax system are fair measures and are good for the nation. We took our tax plans to the people—as Senator Harradine mentioned in his speech—and received, we believe, their support and, we believe, a mandate to implement our election promises.

speech.para: This week's budget, in our view, clearly demonstrated the government's commitment to delivering on its election promises, and that is precisely what we are seeking to do with this legislation now before the chamber. I indicate to the Senate that the government will continue to progress tax reform legislation in this chamber, and we will continue in our plans to get the Senate to pass the legislation and to implement our election promise, which, we say and we believe, is endorsed by the Australian people.

I listened very carefully to the speech of Senator Harradine, and he would understand that there would be much in some of the comments that he made to which I believe very strong and forceful counterarguments can be made. This is not the time to do that in detail. I do stress that, from the government's perspective, this is a fair package. It is a package which we exposed to the people before the election, which we debated at length through the election and which has been subject to the most rigorous scrutiny, I suspect, of any legislation ever to appear before the parliament.

Senator Harradine, as he mentioned, had the courtesy to inform the Prime Minister of his decision today, and it is my understanding that the Prime Minister will be making a statement on that in the near future, and undoubtedly dealing with press questions and other matters which will be raised. But, Senator Harradine, we are sorry to hear what you have said here late this afternoon, but we do appreciate the courtesy with which you took the decision to the Prime Minister.

As I said, from our perspective, we will continue to progress the bills in this parliament. We will continue negotiations in good faith to implement a new tax system, which we believe is fundamentally in the national interest. If we did not believe it was fair, if we have did not believe it was in the national interest, if we did not believe it was good for our children, if we did not believe that this would set up Australia for the 21st century, we would not have put this before the parliament. So the debate has a way to go. As I said, the Prime Minister will be making a statement shortly.

talk.start.para: —At about 3.30 on this day, 14 May, this Senate witnessed what I regard as a statement of great moral courage, and I commend Senator Harradine for it. I know that he has agonised long and hard. I have sat with him during the four months of the Senate inquiry. He attended most of those hearings and took part in nearly all of the examination of all the witnesses.

speech.para: It was an arduous task and, for someone exercising a balance in this, it was a very difficult and complex task that imposed great strain and great pressure. Many of us, if we were placed in that position, would have wilted under the weight of responsibility. I have to acknowledge, and would have said this had Senator Harradine not announced his position, as he has today, that Senator Harradine conducted himself with profound dignity and with great consideration as to the issues.

I came to this debate with a view which, of course, as the debate has unfolded, has been confirmed. We started on the Prime Minister's great tax adventure in August 1997. It has been a long and winding road to this day—14 May. The ANTS package came out in August 1998 and we saw for the first time the published detail in that degree of comprehension. We had an election in October at which 52 per cent of the population on a two-party preferred outcome, in aggregate totals, voted Labor. If that was a referendum on a GST, a majority was not found in sufficient states or in the Commonwealth overall to have passed it. We lost the election because our votes were not distributed strategically in the key seats, but the issue for that election was the GST, and we always believe that the people of Australia stood in opposition to a GST.

It was not the first occasion they had an opportunity to judge. They did so in 1985 at the Tax Summit through organisations representing the broader community. They did it in 1993 at the election that year. I believe that the Senate inquiry that followed the election for the first time served the community of Australia well in this debate. It served it well because it enabled the fine print to be turned to, the detail to be examined and conclusions to be reached on judgments that we were told before the election were good for us.

The conclusion was the unexceptional fact now in retrospect: that a regressive tax requires compensation, that you cannot be sure that a regressive tax will not rise. International experience is that goods and services and consumption taxes always do, and the mechanism to prevent it was never going to do so. A regressive tax requires compensation to protect those at the lower income areas. The question was always: was the compensation adequate? We felt it never was. A turning point in this debate was in the dying minutes of the Senate inquiry when Professors Warren and Harding, giving evidence to the Senate in the presence of the Department of the Treasury, confirmed that, in effect, Treasury had said pensions would erode over a short time and the compensation for pensioners, for that class of Australians, would not exist. That was a turning point in an examination of what was fair in this package.

We always thought that the compensation, even if it was adequate and the pensions did not erode, would not remain eternally true, although the tax would always be there, because succeeding governments would change the compensation mix and, according to the needs of the time—that great expression as a let out—the compensation would fall away. So, when you embarked on this endeavour, we believe that the compensation would never be good enough and it would never be sustained. We believe that the tax cuts were tax cuts that gave with one hand and took with another.

Today in the debate in this chamber, before the Democrats amendment on food was defeated, Senator Meg Lees was asked whether she would vote against the package if that amendment was lost and she said yes. Now I understand from the statement of Senator Harradine that he too will vote against the package. I do not know what the next step in this procedure is, but no doubt we will turn to the detail and laboriously plod on. But what has been said in this chamber marks the end of this package. It was a decision made not by me; it was a decision made by a majority of this chamber.

I commend Senator Harradine in the circumstances, given the pressure placed on him and the difficult situation he has been placed in. He has been true to his moral code, the code he announced to us in his speech at the second reading stage but which we have always known existed, in making the announcement he has today.

talk.start.para: —I remind everybody that, if you are really looking to complete your comments by a quarter to 4, you take that into account.

—I will speak very briefly. In circumstances such as these we are reminded of the mystery and magnificence of human nature because we have just witnessed an individual senator going through the agonies of reconciling a very complex and difficult issue, that is, how you reconcile morality with policy, how you try and conceive the future as a consequence of your personal actions.

speech.para: Senator Harradine is sometimes the butt of cartoons and of media commentary which, quite frankly, is unpleasantly superficial in failing to understand the real responsibility which falls upon a person who happens, through no action of his own, to end up with the balance of power. Whatever our views on this particular package and whatever perspective we have, I just want to record my personal appreciation of the dignity and the manner in which Senator Harradine has dealt with this issue.

The Democrats are going to go away and have a long think about how we should progress, but my view is that the government no longer have the numbers and it might not be very educative to continue ploughing on through what we have before us. It may be an exercise in futility; however, I will leave that to another day. But I do want to record on behalf of the Democrats our recognition of the difficulties you have faced, Senator Harradine, and how well you have coped with them. I acknowledge you, as a senator, accordingly.

talk.start.para: —The Constitution has placed Senator Harradine in a very difficult position, and I think everyone in the Senate would recognise that. He did not write the Constitution, he has to live with it and I do not question his motives for one minute. He is a personal friend of mine, and I know the strain he has been going through. But I would be less than honest with my own constituency if I did not express disappointment on behalf of the people in rural Australia and in small business.

speech.para: There are 25,000 farmers required to feed and clothe Australia. There are about 125,000 that depend on exports to sustain themselves and to gain a living. There was $4½ billion that would have been removed from all exports from Australia. It would have made them more competitive. It would have allowed them to compete and gain some monetary benefits. I point out to the Senate that, unfortunately, the lowest incomes at the moment, because of low commodity prices and low wool prices, are in rural Australia. They will miss out on $4.5 billion. They will miss out on a huge reduction in diesel fuel which would have made their living expenses and their transport of food from the cities into the bush a lot cheaper. They would have got 7c a litre on petrol when it was used for their business, which would have made them a lot more competitive. Small businesses complain at the moment about the $30,000 tax anomaly in the retail area that disadvantages them and which would have been washed out by the GST.

I know Senator Harradine has balanced all these things in his mind. To my constituents, this is going to be a pretty hard blow to wear. I think if something is right—and I believe we are right on this—one thing down here that I have learnt is: do not be afraid of moving forward. Sometimes you have got to. It is comfortable to sit where you are, and no-one is more conservative than the people in the National Party. They get comfortable and sometimes they do not want to move forward. But down here we have got to lean forward. This, to my constituents—and, I think, to people all over Australia—was a forward move and they will be disappointed. But when I say that, Senator Harradine, I in no way question your motives. I think that we should proceed with the debate and then it will be up to the Prime Minister where we go from there.

talk.start.para: —I want to add a word of congratulations to Senator Harradine. I was wrong about the outcome that we have here today, but that is not the important thing, nor is Senator Harradine's decision not to support this package. I think the important thing is the deliberation that he has undertaken in getting to this decision. It is an exemplar of the role of the Senate, which is, amongst other things, to review government legislation on behalf of the people. It is just a pity that the diligence, research and effort that Senator Harradine, along with other people in the Senate, has put into investigating the ramifications of the GST for the people of Australia are not emulated in the House of Representatives.

speech.para: I also want to say that a very heavy responsibility now transfers to the Democrats. They are going to be the party of the GST. They have taken to themselves the responsibility for the GST being introduced to this country. I think that it is a responsibility which they are going to have to bear with a lot of criticism and are going to have to think a lot about. The Democrats now become the GST arbiters. They are going to take the role of ushering the GST into the taxation system of this country with all the ramifications it has on the people of Australia. I think they are wrong in that. I think they have been manifestly wrong since the election campaign in that role. But we will be here to enter that debate on another day.
Progress reported.

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I want to pay a very brief tribute to a long serving, committed Liberal and former Premier of New South Wales, Sir Eric Willis, who died earlier this week. I make my brief comments personally as well as politically because my family had known Sir Eric since 1949. He died, aged 77, after some 28 years in the New South Wales parliament and a distinguished career outside politics. He was from a great Liberal family. His brother Max Willis was a longstanding member and former president of the Legislative Council of New South Wales.

speech.para: Sir Eric was from Murwillumbah in northern New South Wales and was educated there and at the University of Sydney. He served in the AIF in New Guinea and the Philippines in the Second World War. In 1949 he unsuccessfully stood for the then federal seat of Lang in New South Wales, and afterwards contested and won the state seat of Earlwood in 1950. It was there that my family became connected with Sir Eric. My father, also a World War II veteran who served in New Guinea, campaigned with him in Lang in 1949 and even in very recent times Sir Eric has continued to remind me of that connection. When I joined the Liberal Party I joined a branch in the then state seat of Earlwood, which Sir Eric had represented for 28 years, and my family's home in Sydney was only two streets away from the Willis home in the suburb of Bardwell Park.

Sir Eric was deputy leader of the New South Wales parliamentary Liberal Party for some 15 years and Leader of the House for 10 years. It is said that he earned the somewhat forbidding nickname of `Stainless Steel' in that capacity of Leader of the House, although I do understand there are other political stories as to how that may have come about.

During his long parliamentary career he held a broad range of portfolio responsibilities including tourism, sport, labour and industry, education, treasury and Chief Secretary. When he was elected Premier, it was a post he held for only four months because he called an early election which saw the ascension of the first Wran government—and the rest, as they say, was history. When he was elected the Sydney Morning Herald recognised a man of great experience and great political expertise and said:
He is well known for his steadiness and acuity . . . he is a seasoned, highly professional politician.
After that defeat he served as opposition leader for, I think, two years and retired from politics in 1978.
I suspect the things one chooses to recall at the end of a political career are always curious. But Sir Eric, when asked, said:
If I had to pick one achievement of my period as Premier that I might be remembered for in the public mind, it would be the introduction of daylight saving.
I guess it was no surprise to him that the editors of various major metropolitan newspapers continue to this day to receive letters complaining about the removal or otherwise of daylight saving.

He had a very fulfilling post-political career—which I think is the test of whether someone can actually make that transition. Initially after his retirement he became executive director of the Arthritis Foundation. He was also chairman of the first Australian Constitutional Convention—as it was described by Who's Who—held in Sydney in 1973. I regret that I never had the opportunity to discuss that with him.

He was elected to the New South Wales Legislative Assembly 10 times and when he was first elected he was the youngest member of the Assembly. He will be remembered as a great friend and member of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, and even in recent years he was still participating in redistribution deliberations in particular. Only last week his son, Greg Willis, represented Sir Eric at a function in my office in Parramatta because his father was away on holidays.

I know that I reflect the views of many members of the New South Wales division and friends from the New South Wales community, in remembering his contribution to the Liberal Party in New South Wales and also in noting that our sympathies are with his family. He served his party, his parliament and his state with enormous distinction. I would like to echo the words of New South Wales Liberal leader, the Hon. Kerry Chikarovski, in saying that the party has `lost a great figure in our political history'.

subdebate.1.para: The following documents were tabled by the Clerk:

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 July 1998:

question.para: (1) What sanctions has Australia applied to India and Pakistan as a consequence of their ill-advised series of nuclear tests.
(2) How many tests including sub-critical tests have been carried out by India and Pakistan, respectively.

(3) (a) What programs of non-explosive tests, simulations and weapons design oriented research does the department believe are carried out by each nation; and (b) what facilities exists for the conduct of such activities.

(4) How many tests including sub-critical tests have been carried out by the following nations: (a) the United States of America (US); (b) the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Russia; (c) France; (d) China; and (e) the United Kingdom (UK)
(5) What sanctions has Australia ever applied in respect of nuclear tests carried out by each of these nations.

(6) What programs of sub-critical, non-explosive, testing and stockpile maintenance are now carried out by: (a) the US: (i) prior to, and (ii) after, the disbandment of the Division des Applications Militaires on 23 June 1998; (b) Russia: (i) prior to and (ii) after, the disbandment of the Division des Applications Militaires; (c) France: (i) prior to, and (ii) after, the disbandment of the Division des Applications Militaires; (d) China; and (e) the UK.
(7) What facilities exist in each of these countries, of which could be used wholly or partially for the design of nuclear weapons without resort to explosive nuclear tests.
(8) What detail is known of the design, research programs and budgets for facilities such as DAHRT and NIF in the US and BARP in France.
(9) What role is actually played by each of these facilities in stockpile stewardship programs in the US and in their equivalents in France.
(10) What equivalents to these facilities and to the stockpile stewardship programs of the US exist to the Minister's knowledge in China, Russia and the UK.
(11) What would be Australians reaction to a further program of sub-critical tests by each of: (a) the US; (b) Russia; (c) China; (d) India; and (e) Pakistan.
(12) Is the Minister aware of the reluctance of some within the US Congress to ratify the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT).
(13) What steps are being taken to ensure positively that the US does in fact ratify the CTBT along with Russia and China in light of the prompt UK and French ratification of that treaty.
(14) Is the Minister aware of the arguments of some members of the US Congress that the US should not only refuse to ratify the CTBT but that it should actually recommence testing.
(15) What is the attitude of the Minister and department towards such arguments that the CTBT should not be signed and that tests should be recommended by the US.
(16) What proactive steps are being taken to ensure that this never occurs.

(17) What steps can be taken in respect of: (a) a further Pakistani or Indian test; (b) an Israeli test; (c) an Iraqi or North Korean test; (d) a resumption of Chinese testing; (e) a resumption of Russian testing; and (f) a resumption of US testing.
(18) Will Australia recall its ambassador for consultations and apply sanctions in response to testing by any of these nations.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1),(5),(17),(18) Sanctions for nuclear testing: The Government's response to the tests by India and Pakistan was firm—including bilateral measures involving suspension of Ministerial and Senior Officials' visits, defence relations and non-humanitarian aid. The Government's response to the tests has registered strongly with both India and Pakistan. The Government has taken a prominent role in regional and multilateral forums in addressing issues raised by these tests, including at the ARF (Manila, late July), in the Task Group of Senior Officials (London, July and October), and at UNGA 53.

The Government's primary objective in responding to the nuclear tests remains to work for a concerted international resolve to deny India and Pakistan any special status consequent on the tests, and to continue to exert pressure on the two States to move towards compliance with the ten demands set out in Security Council Resolution 1172 of 6 June 1998. India and Pakistan have made some progress towards fulfilling these benchmarks. They have reopened a bilateral dialogue with some limited progress reached in areas of trade and people to people exchanges. Both countries withdrew their opposition to commencing negotiations on a Fissile Material Cut-Off Treaty. They have both announced a caveated intention to adhere to the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. They have also signalled a willingness to formalise through national export controls their pledges not to export sensitive nuclear technology. These are welcome gestures and we look forward to their early implementation.

These moves have led a number of countries, including the United States and Japan, to revisit some of their measures imposed against India and Pakistan in the wake of the tests. This is intended to encourage India and Pakistan to continue to move towards implementing the requirements of UNSCR 1172. Against this background, the Government reviewed the measures it adopted in response to the tests, and decided that it would be appropriate to relax our suspension of ministerial and senior official visits. The Government considers that the pursuit of bilateral dialogues with India and Pakistan are an integral part of encouraging the two countries to make progress towards meeting UNSCR 1172. The resumption of a high-level bilateral dialogue will allow more regular discussions about our concerns arising from the nuclear tests and the tensions existing between India and Pakistan and the implications for Australia and the region of the nuclearisation of South Asia, as well as on the range of economic, political, security and other matters in which we have a mutual interest with Pakistan and India. The Government's suspension on the provision of non humanitarian aid to both countries remains, as well as the suspension on bilateral defence relations.

The Government's response to nuclear tests has been—and will continue to be—appropriate and proportionate and seeks to underline the clear message from Australia and the overwhelming majority of the international community as regards the need to demonstrate a genuine commitment to the international nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament regime. The issue of what actions Australia may take in response to future tests would have to be examined in the light of circumstances at the time and on a case by case basis.

(2) Successive Australian Governments have consistently opposed and, as appropriate, protested at nuclear tests carried out by any state. India conducted one nuclear explosion in 1974. The Government of India announced it had detonated three nuclear explosions on 11 May 1998, while the Government of Pakistan announced it had detonated five nuclear explosions on 28 May. For these two cases only one seismic signal each was recorded on Australian seismic stations indicating that all explosions were detonated simultaneously or that only one was large enough to be recorded.

The Indian Government further announced the conduct of two sub-kilotonne explosions on 13 May 1998. Despite an intensive search, including of the seismograph records of the Pakistan seismic station at Nilore, no signals from these events have been found. The Government of Pakistan announced that it conducted one nuclear explosion on 30 May, for which a seismic signal was detected.

(3) (a) and (b) the Government is unable to verify the detail of what, if any, programs of non-explosive experiments, simulations and weapons design orientated research is being conducted by the Governments of India and Pakistan. Nonetheless, by conducting nuclear explosions, both India and Pakistan have demonstrated the capacity to develop nuclear explosive devices, and it is clear that appropriate facilities have been developed for this purpose by both countries. It is not possible to verify the degree of nuclear weaponisation by India and Pakistan.

(4) The number of nuclear weapons test explosions conducted by the five nuclear weapon states according to the Arms Control Association and published in its journal `Arms Control Today': (a) USA—1030; (b) USSR/Russia—715; (c) France—210; (d) China—45; (e) UK—45. The ACA is a reputable non-profit membership organisation, based in the United States, dedicated to promoting public understanding and support for effective arms control policies.

Since the opening for signature of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT), the United States of America has conducted sub-critical experiments at the Nevada nuclear test site, on the following dates: 2 July and 15 September 1997, 25 March, 26 September and 9 December 1998. There were some media reports that Russia may have carried out a sub-critical experiment at its nuclear test site at Novaya Zemlya in August 1997. Russia made a public announcement of a sub-critical experiment conducted at Novaya Zemlya in December 1998. France, China or the United Kingdom have not announced details of any sub-critical experiments, if any, and such programs cannot be independently verified. Sub-critical experiments are not prohibited by the CTBT.
(6) to (10) (Research & Design Facilities) As a non-nuclear weapon state, Australia is not privy to the requirements of nuclear weapons development and maintenance.
All the five nuclear weapon states have nuclear weapons maintenance programs, all of which vary according to the different nature of their weapons:

United States: The United States Department of Energy (DOE) has responsibility for the U.S. "Stockpile Stewardship and Management Program" . Research Laboratories (US): National Ignition Facility (NIF): (Laboratory facility housing laser equipment designed to facilitate experiments into nuclear weapons physics without underground testing); Los Alamos National Laboratory (stockpile stewardship and materials management); Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (stockpile stewardship and materials management); Sandia National Laboratories (design of non-nuclear components of nuclear weapons); Rocky Flats Plant (environmental technology site / site cleanup); Pantex Plant (weapons assembly/disassembly), SOURCE: Nuclear Weapons Databook (NWD); DOE Internet Homepage.

France: In reference to "BARP" (Question 8) , there is a French facility at Le Barp, 30 km south of Bordeaux (The Centre d'Etudes Scientifiques et Techniques d'Aquitaine—CESTA) a research facility under the French Atomic Energy Agency. "CESTA's principal mission is to militarise nuclear warheads in ways comparable to what is being done by the U.S. Defense Nuclear Agency and Sandia National Laboratories.": SOURCE: NWD. Other research related to maintenance of the nuclear stockpile in France is conducted by the Centre d'Etudes du Ripault under the French Atomic Energy Agency. SOURCE: NWD
Russia: Minatom, Chelyabinsk-70; SOURCE: US DOE, September 1995;
China: Chinese Academy of Engineering Physics; SOURCE: NWD;
UK: Atomic Weapons Establishment (AWE), Aldermaston.

(11) The five Nuclear Weapons States (NWS—United States, Russia, China, United Kingdom and France) signed the CTBT on 24 September 1996. They are committed to never again conduct a nuclear test explosion. Sub-critical nuclear experiments conducted by the NWS are not inconsistent with their obligations under the CTBT, and are intended to ensure that existing nuclear stockpiles are maintained in a safe and reliable condition. The Government accepts that, as the Nuclear Weapon States recognised by the NPT work towards the ultimate elimination of nuclear weapons as required by that Treaty, it is in everyone's interest that their arsenals are safely maintained The Government would not intend to comment on activities conducted by any of the which were consistent with their obligations under the NPT and the CTBT.

In contrast, the conduct of any sub-critical nuclear experiments by India and/or Pakistan would be designed to develop new nuclear weapons capability. The Government would regard such experiments conducted by India and/or Pakistan, as acting outside the norm of the NPT which limits nuclear weapons possession—and therefore maintenance and development activities—to the five NWS. Through their signature of the NPT, the NWS which existed in 1968 have committed themselves towards working towards eventual nuclear disarmament. India and Pakistan have not.

(13) The US Administration has made it clear that it places important priority on US ratification of the CTBT. President Clinton has stated this objective repeatedly, including in the State of the Union Address, and in the wake of Indian and Pakistani nuclear testing, where the President said in May this year that "Now it's all the more important that the Senate act quickly, this year, so that we can increase the pressure on, and isolation of, other nations that may be considering their own nuclear test explosions." (more proactive, JSCOT recommendation)
(14) Yes, although I would note that the arguments in favour of recommencement of nuclear testing by the US are very much the views of the minority.

(15) The US was the first country to sign the CTBT, on 24 September 1996. President Clinton has sent the CTBT to the Senate for ratification as soon as possible. It is the strong conviction of the Government that ratification of the CTBT would be the single most important step the US could make in support of the global norm against nuclear weapons testing, and would serve as a strong incentive for other countries—nuclear weapon states and non-nuclear weapon states—to likewise ratify the Treaty, and bring it closer to entry into force.

(16) The Government will continue to make regular representations to the US, China and Russia—and to all other countries which have not yet signed or ratified the CTBT—urging them to do so as soon as possible. The US Government has on no occasion given any indication of an intention of going back on its commitment indicated by its signature of the CTBT permanently to cease nuclear weapon explosive testing. All nuclear weapon states have reiterated their commitment to the CTBT in the wake of Indian and Pakistani nuclear testing—statements which we welcome as evidence of their intention to stand by their signatures of the Treaty, and in the case of the UK and France, their absolute legal commitment as demonstrated by their ratification on 6 April.
